blog.name: rainhadaenerys
blog.title: Daenerys Targaryen is the love of my life

summary: Daenerys as a leader and a ruler
title: Daenerys as a leader and a ruler
body:
For the longest time, I wanted to write about Dany as a leader and a ruler. Most of the time, the metas I see from Dany haters just talk about what an awful ruler Dany is, and amongst Daenerys fans, this is usually not discussed a lot, mostly because I think Dany fans spend a lot of time defending Dany from the accusations that she is evil or mad, so other subjects are neglected. Before I start, I just want to make it clear that I am not any expert on medieval politics or war strategy, so this will be mostly my understanding of the story. And of course, I can’t forget to mention that many of the ideas of the Meereenese Blot are here as well, but this is going to be my interpretation.

In this analysis, I will show why I think Daenerys is an intelligent and capable leader and ruler. I want to look at everything we know about Dany in all of the books: her childhood and education, her political beliefs, her actions and the economic and political situation she’s in. I’ll try to focus on what Dany has learned in each book, and how it helped her become a better leader.

Some of the things I’ll write here are similar to metas that I’ve written before. But I want this one to be as complete as possible, and to analyze every facet of Dany’s storyline as a ruler that I can think of. I will bring book quotes to back up what I say, so this will be very long (It’s around 20k words, so I hope at least someone will be interested in reading it, because I spent months scrutinizing all of the books to write this).

In this essay, I will talk about the following topics:

Dany’s childhood and education

Dany’s intelligence, wisdom and introspectiveness

Dany’s changing political views

Dany journey as a leader in A Game of Thrones

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Clash of Kings

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Storm of Swords

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Dance with Dragons:

  • Economy
  • The war against Yunkai and the question of peace and war
  • The question of taking the wealth of the slave masters
  • Conflicting interests within the city
  • Morality
  • Practical aspects or ruling
  • Dany’s equalitarian practices
  • Some mistakes worth addressing

Is Daenerys a good ruler? What did she learn?

DANY’S CHILDHOOD AND EDUCATION

Dany spent her childhood poor, homeless, and had to go from place to place, never stopping for too long. She didn’t have money or stability to have a formal education:

After Ser Willem had died, the servants had stolen what little money they had left, and soon after they had been put out of the big house. Dany had cried when the red door closed behind them forever.

They had wandered since then, from Braavos to Myr, from Myr to Tyrosh, and on to Qohor and Volantis and Lys, never staying long in any one place. Her brother would not allow it. The Usurper’s hired knives were close behind them, he insisted, though Dany had never seen one.

At first the magisters and archons and merchant princes were pleased to welcome the last Targaryens to their homes and tables, but as the years passed and the Usurper continued to sit upon the Iron Throne, doors closed and their lives grew meaner. Years past they had been forced to sell their last few treasures, and now even the coin they had gotten from Mother’s crown had gone. In the alleys and wine sinks of Pentos, they called her brother “the beggar king.” Dany did not want to know what they called her. – Daenerys I AGOT

Dany later confirms that she indeed never had any formal education:

“Tell me of this other Daenerys. I know less than I should of the history of my father’s kingdom. I never had a maester growing up.” Only a brother. – Daenerys VIII ADWD

But we also have this quote:

“A queen must listen to all,” […] She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

Dany spent her childhood poor, homeless, without receiving a formal education. Most of what Dany knows comes from Viserys, from her own experience, and from a few books she has read. Given that Dany and Viserys were poor, I imagine that the only times that Dany had access to books were when they were guests at some archon’s or prince’s home, and this was only in the beginning, before the doors started closing on them. I think this is the first thing we need to know if we want to understand Dany’s mistakes and beliefs, and not crucify her for them. Daenerys is not supposed to start the story as a great leader who makes no mistakes. Her story, from the very beginning, is all about learning.

DANY’S INTELLIGENCE, WISDOM AND INTROSPECTIVENESS

Despite lacking education and experience, Dany shows herself to be very intelligent and wise.

Dany is observant, always aware of her situation, surroundings and of the people around her:

Magister Illyrio was a dealer in spices, gemstones, dragonbone, and other, less savory things. He had friends in all of the Nine Free Cities, it was said, and even beyond, in Vaes Dothrak and the fabled lands beside the Jade Sea. It was also said that he’d never had a friend he wouldn’t cheerfully sell for the right price. Dany listened to the talk in the streets, and she heard these things, but she knew better than to question her brother when he wove his webs of dream. – Daenerys I AGOT

The cobbler thanked her for that, and the old brickmaker kissed her foot, but the weaver looked at her with eyes as hard as slate. She knows I lie, the queen thought. - Daenerys V ADWD

She is not gullible:

“Why does he give us so much?” she asked. “What does he want from us?” For nigh on half a year, they had lived in the magister’s house, eating his food, pampered by his servants. Dany was thirteen, old enough to know that such gifts seldom come without their price, here in the free city of Pentos. – Daenerys I AGOT

“They are your people, and they love you well,” Magister Illyrio said amiably. “In holdfasts all across the realm, men lift secret toasts to your health while women sew dragon banners and hide them against the day of your return from across the water.” He gave a massive shrug. “Or so my agents tell me.”

Dany had no agents, no way of knowing what anyone was doing or thinking across the narrow sea, but she mistrusted Illyrio’s sweet words as she mistrusted everything about Illyrio. – Daenerys I AGOT

Dany took the warlock’s words well salted, but the magnificence of the great city was not to be denied. – Daenerys II ACOK

“I do not understand her.” Pyat and Xaro had showered Dany with promises from the moment they first glimpsed her dragons, declaring themselves her loyal servants in all things, but from Quaithe she had gotten only the rare cryptic word. And it disturbed her that she had never seen the woman’s face. Remember Mirri Maz Duur, she told herself. Remember treachery. She turned to her bloodriders. “We will keep our own watch so long as we are here. See that no one enters this wing of the palace without my leave, and take care that the dragons are always well guarded.” – Daenerys II ACOK

Thirteen. To be sure. Xaro was one of the Thirteen. No doubt he had convinced each of his fellow members to give up one ship. She knew the merchant prince too well to think that he would sacrifice thirteen of his own ships. “I must consider this. May I inspect these ships?”

“You have grown suspicious, Daenerys.”

Always. “I have grown wise, Xaro.” - Daenerys III ADWD

But at the same time, Dany is not paranoid, and she knows that she needs to take risks to get what she wants or needs:

“It seems to me that a queen who trusts no one is as foolish as a queen who trusts everyone. Every man I take into my service is a risk, I understand that, but how am I to win the Seven Kingdoms without such risks? Am I to conquer Westeros with one exile knight and three Dothraki bloodriders?” – Daenerys I ASOS

“I am glad you came to me. It is good to see your face again, my friend.” I will not trust you, but I need you. I need your Thirteen, I need your ships, I need your trade. - Daenerys III ADWD

We continue to see this attitude in all of the books, with good, bad and uncertain results: Dany trusts Barristan, which was a good thing. Despite being warned by Quaithe’s prophecies and the prophecies of the House of the Undying, Dany is not paranoid about them. She is aware of the danger from Reznak (who she thinks is the perfumed seneschal) and Quentyn (the Sun’s son), the danger from sellswords and people in her court, but she tries to make use of everyone even though she doesn’t fully trust them, trying not to be gullible but without being paranoid.

Dany is very adaptable and respects different cultures, which enables her to survive different situations, while her brother fails:

Viserys came upon her as sudden as a summer storm, his horse rearing beneath him as he reined up too hard. “You dare!” he screamed at her. “You give commands to me? To me?” He vaulted off the horse, stumbling as he landed. His face was flushed as he struggled back to his feet. He grabbed her, shook her. “Have you forgotten who you are? Look at you. Look at you!”

Dany did not need to look. She was barefoot, with oiled hair, wearing Dothraki riding leathers and a painted vest given her as a bride gift. She looked as though she belonged here. Viserys was soiled and stained in city silks and ringmail. – Daenerys III AGOT

She’s also very introspective, capable of reflecting on her experiences and mistakes, and always tries to learn and improve. One of the things she tries to improve is her magical knowledge:

“I thank you, Mirri Maz Duur,” she said, “for the lessons you have taught me.”

“You will not hear me scream,” Mirri responded as the oil dripped from her hair and soaked her clothing.

“I will,” Dany said, “but it is not your screams I want, only your life. I remember what you told me. Only death can pay for life.” – Daenerys X AGOT

And when Dany’s bloodriders and Ser Jorah tell Dany to not enter the House of The Undying, Dany tells them that the reason she wants to go is to obtain more knowledge:

Ser Jorah Mormont gave the merchant prince a sour look. “Your Grace, remember Mirri Maz Duur.”

“I do,” Dany said, suddenly decided. “I remember that she had knowledge. And she was only a maegi.” – Daenerys IV ACOK

She tries to improve her military knowledge:

Dany reined in her mare and looked across the fields, to where the Yunkish host lay athwart her path. Whitebeard had been teaching her how best to count the numbers of a foe. “Five thousand,” she said after a moment. – Daenerys IV ASOS

She loves books, and tries to learn from them:

Ser Jorah Mormont apologized for his gift. “It is a small thing, my princess, but all a poor exile could afford,” he said as he laid a small stack of old books before her. They were histories and songs of the Seven Kingdoms, she saw, written in the Common Tongue. She thanked him with all her heart. – Daenerys II AGOT

“A queen must listen to all,”[…] She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

“I’m cold,” Dany lied. “Bring me the book I was reading last night.” She wanted to lose herself in the words, in other times and other places. The fat leather-bound volume was full of songs and stories from the Seven Kingdoms. Children’s stories, if truth be told; too simple and fanciful to be true history. All the heroes were tall and handsome, and you could tell the traitors by their shifty eyes. Yet she loved them all the same. Last night she had been reading of the three princesses in the red tower, locked away by the king for the crime of being beautiful. – Daenerys VI ASOS

Dragons are fire made flesh. She had read that in one of the books Ser Jorah had given her as a wedding gift. – Daenerys I ADWD

“You … you mean to ride them?”

“One of them. All I know of dragons is what my brother told me when I was a girl, and some I read in books, but it is said that even Aegon the Conqueror never dared mount Vhagar or Meraxes, nor did his sisters ride Balerion the Black Dread. Dragons live longer than men, some for hundreds of years, so Balerion had other riders after Aegon died … but no rider ever flew two dragons.” – Daenerys VIII ADWD

She always tries to listen to people, and use their advice when she lacks the necessary knowledge:

“A queen must listen to all,” she reminded him. “The highborn and the low, the strong and the weak, the noble and the venal. One voice may speak you false, but in many there is always truth to be found.” She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

The old man had not wanted to sail to Astapor; nor did he favor buying this slave army. A queen should hear all sides before reaching a decision. That was why Dany had brought him with her to the Plaza of Pride, not to keep her safe. – Daenerys II ASOS

“Aggo, Jhoqo, and Rakharo still serve me.” He is playing games with me. Dany could play as well. “I am only a young girl and know little of such things, but older, wiser men tell me that to hold Meereen I must control its hinterlands, all the land west of Lhazar as far south as the Yunkish hills.” – Daenerys III ADWD

Dany had no answer for that. If this is truly what my people wish, do I have the right to deny it to them? It was their city before it was mine, and it is their own lives they wish to squander. “I will consider all you’ve said. Thank you for your counsel.” She rose. “We will resume on the morrow.” – Daenerys II ADWD

Dany is also very introspective and self critical, always reflecting on her experiences and mistakes, and deciding that she needs to learn how to rule:

That morning she summoned her captains and commanders to the garden, rather than descending to the audience chamber. “Aegon the Conqueror brought fire and blood to Westeros, but afterward he gave them peace, prosperity, and justice. But all I have brought to Slaver’s Bay is death and ruin. I have been more khal than queen, smashing and plundering, then moving on.”

[…]

“You have brought freedom as well,” Missandei pointed out.

“Freedom to starve?” asked Dany sharply. “Freedom to die? Am I a dragon, or a harpy?” Am I mad? Do I have the taint?

“A dragon,” Ser Barristan said with certainty. “Meereen is not Westeros, Your Grace.”

“But how can I rule seven kingdoms if I cannot rule a single city?” He had no answer to that. Dany turned away from them, to gaze out over the city once again. “My children need time to heal and learn. My dragons need time to grow and test their wings. And I need the same. I will not let this city go the way of Astapor. I will not let the harpy of Yunkai chain up those I’ve freed all over again.” She turned back to look at their faces. “I will not march.”

“What will you do then, Khaleesi?” asked Rakharo.

“Stay,” she said. “Rule. And be a queen.” – Daenerys VI ASOS

“Your Grace could not have known—”

“I am the queen. It was my place to know.” – Daenerys V ADWD

She also knows that she needs to learn more about the kingdom that she intends to rule:

“Tell me of this other Daenerys. I know less than I should of the history of my father’s kingdom. I never had a maester growing up.” Only a brother. – Daenerys VIII ADWD

This gift for self-reflection is something we see constantly in ADWD as well, while Dany ponders what’s the best course of action in Meereen.

Dany is pragmatic. In Vaes Tolorro, her people don’t want to enter the city out of fear, but Dany insists:

“I fear no ghosts. Dragons are more powerful than ghosts.” And figs are more important. – Daenerys I ACOK

We can also see her pragmatism in relation to war and conquest:

The thought of home disquieted her. If her sun-and-stars had lived, he would have led his khalasar across the poison water and swept away her enemies, but his strength had left the world. Her bloodriders remained, sworn to her for life and skilled in slaughter, but only in the ways of the horselords. The Dothraki sacked cities and plundered kingdoms, they did not rule them. Dany had no wish to reduce King’s Landing to a blackened ruin full of unquiet ghosts. She had supped enough on tears. I want to make my kingdom beautiful, to fill it with fat men and pretty maids and laughing children. I want my people to smile when they see me ride by, the way Viserys said they smiled for my father.

But before she could do that she must conquer. – Daenerys II ACOK

“My queen,” said Arstan, “there have been no slaves in the Seven Kingdoms for thousands of years. The old gods and the new alike hold slavery to be an abomination. Evil. If you should land in Westeros at the head of a slave army, many good men will oppose you for no other reason than that. You will do great harm to your cause, and to the honor of your House.”

“Yet I must have some army,” Dany said. “The boy Joffrey will not give me the Iron Throne for asking politely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

Dany is politically intelligent. She very easily sees the political consequences of Robert’s death (she doesn’t have the full picture, but she very quickly understands the flaws in her reasoning when Jorah points it out):

“Before, the Seven Kingdoms were like my Drogo's khalasar, a hundred thousand made as one by his strength. Now they fly to pieces, even as the khalasar did after my khal lay dead.” – Daenerys II ACOK

She can see Hizdahr’s true intention behind the reopening of the fighting pits, and she’s capable of making an analysis of the political and economic situation she’s in:

I need this man, Dany reminded herself. Hizdahr was a wealthy merchant with many friends in Meereen, and more across the seas. He had visited Volantis, Lys, and Qarth, had kin in Tolos and Elyria, and was even said to wield some influence in New Ghis, where the Yunkai'i were trying to stir up enmity against Dany and her rule.

And he was rich. Famously and fabulously rich …

And like to grow richer, if I grant his petition. When Dany had closed the city's fighting pits, the value of pit shares had plummeted. Hizdahr zo Loraq had grabbed them up with both hands, and now owned most of the fighting pits in Meereen. – Daenerys I ADWD

A brothel. Half of her freedmen were from Yunkai, where the Wise Masters had been famed for training bedslaves. The way of the seven sighs. Brothels had sprouted up like mushrooms all over Meereen. It is all they know. They need to survive. Food was more costly every day, whilst the price of flesh grew cheaper. In the poorer districts between the stepped pyramids of Meereen’s slaver nobility, there were brothels catering to every conceivable erotic taste, she knew. - Daenerys I ADWD

She understands supply and demand:

“I am trying to set a price on one of the three living dragons in the world.“ Dany smiled at him sweetly. "It seems to me that one-third of all the ships in the world would be fair.” – Daenerys V ACOK

She understands the need to compromise, and that it’s not enough to conquer a city, she also needs to win over the people:

To rule Meereen I must win the Meereenese, however much I may despise them. - Daenerys I ADWD

She understands that she needs to be careful about keeping up appearances and manipulating how other people perceive her:

That was Drogon's victory, not mine, Dany wanted to say, but she held her tongue. The Dothraki would esteem her all the more for a few bells in her hair. – Daenerys V ACOK

“Whitebeard,” she said, “I want your counsel, and you should never fear to speak your mind with me … when we are alone. But never question me in front of strangers. Is that understood?” – Daenerys III ASOS

The rest of her people followed: Groleo and the other captains and their crews, and the eighty-three Dothraki who remained to her of the hundred thousand who had once ridden in Drogo’s khalasar. She put the oldest and weakest on the inside of the column, with the nursing women and those with child, and the little girls, and the boys too young to braid their hair. The rest—her warriors, such as they were—rode outside and moved their dismal herd along, the hundred-odd gaunt horses that had survived both red waste and black salt sea. – Daenerys III ASOS

She thinks a ruler must keep a cool head and be merciful:

If I wed Hizdahr, will that turn Skahaz against me? She trusted Skahaz more than she trusted Hizdahr, but the Shavepate would be a disaster as a king. He was too quick to anger, too slow to forgive. - Daenerys IV ADWD

She understands that she needs to be seen caring for her people:

“Go if you wish, ser. I will not detain you. I will not detain any of you.” Dany vaulted down from the horse. “I cannot heal them, but I can show them that their Mother cares.” - Daenerys VI ADWD

But even though she has to keep up appearances, she tries to be just:

Her name had been Hazzea. She was four years old. Unless her father lied. He might have lied. No one had seen the dragon but him. His proof was burned bones, but burned bones proved nothing. He might have killed the little girl himself, and burned her afterward. He would not have been the first father to dispose of an unwanted girl child, the Shavepate claimed. The Sons of the Harpy might have done it, and made it look like dragon’s work to make the city hate me. Dany wanted to believe that … but if that was so, why had Hazzea’s father waited until the audience hall was almost empty to come forward? If his purpose had been to inflame the Meereenese against her, he would have told his tale when the hall was full of ears to hear.

The Shavepate had urged her to put the man to death. “At least rip out his tongue. This man’s lie could destroy us all, Magnificence.” Instead Dany chose to pay the blood price. No one could tell her the worth of a daughter, so she set it at one hundred times the worth of a lamb. “I would give Hazzea back to you if I could,” she told the father, “but some things are beyond the power of even a queen. Her bones shall be laid to rest in the Temple of the Graces, and a hundred candles shall burn day and night in her memory. Come back to me each year upon her nameday, and your other children shall not want … but this tale must never pass your lips again.” – Daenerys II ADWD

This quote shows that Dany is smart and capable of analysing the situation to conclude that Hazzea’s father was telling the truth. She knows that she has to keep the tale from spreading, but she also understands that it’s important to be fair to her people, so she chooses to be kind and be just to Hazzea’s father.

With all of this being said, I think Dany has many qualities of a great ruler.

DANY’S CHANGING POLITICAL VIEWS

Thanks to Dany’s ability for self-reflection, Dany changes her political views throughout the story due to her experiences. She starts the story as a very naïve girl who doesn’t truly understands the costs of war and conquest, asking her husband to invade the Seven Kingdoms without really realizing what the consequences would be. First, she tries to convince Drogo several times, unsuccessfully. Then, the wineseller tries to poison her and Drogo decides to cross the narrow sea. He attacks the Lhazareen to pay for the ships, and Dany finally sees the consequences of her actions:

Slaves, Dany thought. Khal Drogo would drive them downriver to one of the towns on Slaver’s Bay. She wanted to cry, but she told herself that she must be strong. This is war, this is what it looks like, this is the price of the Iron Throne. – Daenerys VII AGOT

But Dany is unable to ignore the horror, and two paragraphs later, she tries to put a stop at least to the rapes, with the little power she has. She defies Dothraki culture and Drogo’s men, putting herself at risk:

Behind them, the girl being raped made a heartrending sound, a long sobbing wail that went on and on and on. Dany’s hand clenched hard around the reins, and she turned the silver’s head. “Make them stop,” she commanded Ser Jorah. – Daenerys VII AGOT

Later, Dany reflects on what she thinks is acceptable in war and conquest, trying to be pragmatic but without unnecessary bloodshed:

Blood and fire, thought Dany. The words of House Targaryen. She had known them all her life. “The blood of my enemies I will shed gladly. The blood of innocents is another matter. Eight thousand Unsullied they would offer me. Eight thousand dead babes. Eight thousand strangled dogs.” – Daenerys II ASOS

“Your Grace,” she corrected. “Prince Rhaegar led free men into battle, not slaves. Whitebeard said he dubbed his squires himself, and made many other knights as well.”

“There was no higher honor than to receive your knighthood from the Prince of Dragonstone.”

“Tell me, then—when he touched a man on the shoulder with his sword, what did he say? ‘Go forth and kill the weak’? Or 'Go forth and defend them’? At the Trident, those brave men Viserys spoke of who died beneath our dragon banners—did they give their lives because they believed in Rhaegar’s cause, or because they had been bought and paid for?” Dany turned to Mormont, crossed her arms, and waited for an answer. – Daenerys II ASOS

Another thing that changes are her views on slavery. Dany starts as someone who lives in a slave society and has no strong feelings against slavery. While she was living with Illyrio, she had slaves serving her, and with the Dothraki, she had slave servants as well. But as soon as Drogo dies, Dany frees her slaves. Even then, while Dany no longer has slaves herself, she has no strong feelings about the slaves in Qarth, and even considers buying a slave army. But when Dany sees the horrors in Astapor and understands what slavery truly means, she turns away from it:

Xaro caught it in the air and took a bite. “Whence came this madness? Should I count myself fortunate that you did not free my own slaves when you were my guest in Qarth?”

I was a beggar queen and you were Xaro of the Thirteen, Dany thought, and all you wanted were my dragons. “Your slaves seemed well treated and content. It was not till Astapor that my eyes were opened. Do you know how Unsullied are made and trained?” – Daenerys III ADWD

And despite being raised by Viserys, Dany was able to think on her on view on what a king should be, and what are her duties as a monarch:

“I was alone for a long time, Jorah. All alone but for my brother. I was such a small scared thing. Viserys should have protected me, but instead he hurt me and scared me worse. He shouldn’t have done that. He wasn’t just my brother, he was my king. Why do the gods make kings and queens, if not to protect the ones who can’t protect themselves?”

“Some kings make themselves. Robert did.”

“He was no true king,” Dany said scornfully. “He did no justice. Justice … that’s what kings are for.” – Daenerys III ASOS

A queen belongs not to herself but to her people. – Daenerys V ADWD

Daenerys was only able to change her views and become a more conscious ruler because of her self-reflection and empathy, and this is one of the things that sets her apart as a leader. With all that being said, let’s see Dany’s journey in each of the books.

FINDING HER WAY IN THE WORLD

The first two books are, in my opinion, about Daenerys finding out what she wants and what to do. It’s the beginning of her journey as a leader, and she’s going on instinct, trying to find out what to do.

A GAME OF THRONES

People usually look at this book as the story of a scared little girl overcoming abuse and becoming stronger. This is all true, but this is also the book where Dany starts to develop her leadership skills. In this book, Dany learns how to be more assertive and how to deal with this new authority that is given to her:

“Wait here,” Dany told Ser Jorah. “Tell them all to stay. Tell them I command it.”

The knight smiled. Ser Jorah was not a handsome man. He had a neck and shoulders like a bull, and coarse black hair covered his arms and chest so thickly that there was none left for his head. Yet his smiles gave Dany comfort. “You are learning to talk like a queen, Daenerys.”

“Not a queen,” said Dany. “A khaleesi.” She wheeled her horse about and galloped down the ridge alone. – Daenerys III AGOT

Unlike Viserys, Dany learns about Dothraki culture and adapts to it. This allows her to gain more respect than her brother:

“Take his horse,” Dany commanded Ser Jorah. Viserys gaped at her. He could not believe what he was hearing; nor could Dany quite believe what she was saying. Yet the words came. “Let my brother walk behind us back to the khalasar.” Among the Dothraki, the man who does not ride was no man at all, the lowest of the low, without honor or pride. “Let everyone see him as he is.” – Daenerys III AGOT

Dany understands that Dothraki culture strongly associates strength with the ability to ride. So she makes a conscious choice to show all of the khalasar what Viserys really is, showing herself stronger than her brother. And we start to see just how much Viserys ignorance is detrimental to his potential ability to lead the Dothraki:

(…) the Dothraki had laughingly called him Khal Rhae Mhar, the Sorefoot King. Khal Drogo had offered him a place in a cart the next day, and Viserys had accepted. In his stubborn ignorance, he had not even known he was being mocked; the carts were for eunuchs, cripples, women giving birth, the very young and the very old. That won him yet another name: Khal Rhaggat, the Cart King. Her brother had thought it was the khal’s way of apologizing for the wrong Dany had done him. She had begged Ser Jorah not to tell him the truth, lest he be shamed. – Daenerys IV AGOT

Because Viserys refuses to learn and adapt to other cultures, he loses respects, while Dany gains the respect of the Dothraki. She respects their culture and shows her strength by eating the stallion’s horse, riding with them until the end of her pregnancy, and asserting herself.

This new authority that Dany gains also means that Dany sees herself more and more free of her brother’s influence. She gets the chance of getting a new perspective on Westeros through Jorah, without her brother’s biases:

“The common people pray for rain, healthy children, and a summer that never ends,” Ser Jorah told her. “It is no matter to them if the high lords play their game of thrones, so long as they are left in peace.” He gave a shrug. “They never are.”

Dany rode along quietly for a time, working his words like a puzzle box. It went against everything that Viserys had ever told her to think that the people could care so little whether a true king or a usurper reigned over them. Yet the more she thought on Jorah’s words, the more they rang of truth. – Daenerys III AGOT

She talks with Jorah about if it would be possible for the Dothraki to conquer Westeros, trying to gather the information that she’ll need, and even starts believing that someone else could conquer the Seven Kingdoms (herself):

Dany could not pretend to surprise at the disdain in his tone. “What … what if it were not Viserys?” she asked. “If it were someone else who led them? Someone stronger? Could the Dothraki truly conquer the Seven Kingdoms?” - Daenerys IV AGOT

This is also the book in which Dany starts dealing with the many moral dilemmas that she encounters in her story: she wants to conquer the Seven Kingdoms, but once she sees that Drogo attacks the Lhazareen to fund the invasion, she sees the costs of war for the first time, and stands up to Drogo’s men to protect the women from being raped. Later, after Drogo dies, Dany frees her slaves and asks people to follow her, promising to protect them and care for them:

“You will be my khalasar,” she told them. “I see the faces of slaves. I free you. Take off your collars. Go if you wish, no one shall harm you. If you stay, it will be as brothers and sisters, husbands and wives.” The black eyes watched her, wary, expressionless. “I see the children, women, the wrinkled faces of the aged. I was a child yesterday. Today I am a woman. Tomorrow I will be old. To each of you I say, give me your hands and your hearts, and there will always be a place for you.” – Daenerys X AGOT

But it’s important to note that even though Dany has more power than she starts the book with, for most of the book, the power is not truly hers, it comes from Drogo. Before Dany hatches her dragons, she has to use Drogo’s name to make herself be obeyed, and has to resort to things like bed tricks. Even then, she is not always successful. I think it’s very interesting that before Dany truly has her own power, she has to deal with what any woman would have to deal – trying to manipulate her husband to have power and get what she wants. It’s only at the end of the book that Dany steps up as khaleesi in her own right. Initially, Aggo, Jhogo and Rakharo refuse to follow her because she’s a woman, but Dany insists, because she knows that when she steps out of the fire and shows her strength, the khalasar will follow her:

Wordless, the knight fell to his knees. The men of her khas came up behind him. Jhogo was the first to lay his arakh at her feet. “Blood of my blood,” he murmured, pushing his face to the smoking earth. “Blood of my blood,” she heard Aggo echo. “Blood of my blood,” Rakharo shouted.

And after them came her handmaids, and then the others, all the Dothraki, men and women and children, and Dany had only to look at their eyes to know that they were hers now, today and tomorrow and forever, hers as they had never been Drogo’s. – Daenerys X AGOT

A Game of Thrones is an essential part of Dany’s growth as a leader. She learns that to be respected and accepted, she needs to integrate into the community and understand the culture that she is in. She gains a new perspective on Westeros and on war, frees herself from Viserys’ abuse, and builds the necessary strength and confidence to lead her people in the future.

A CLASH OF KINGS

Now, for the first time in her life, Dany has power on her own, and people look up to her for guidance. To survive the Red Waste, Dany leads by showing an example of strength:

They are not strong, she told herself, so I must be their strength. I must show no fear, no weakness, no doubt. However frightened my heart, when they look upon my face they must see only Drogo’s queen. She felt older than her fourteen years. If ever she had truly been a girl, that time was done. – Daenerys I ACOK

She keeps her people together by respecting their culture and traditions:

Three days into the march, the first man died. A toothless oldster with cloudy blue eyes, he fell exhausted from his saddle and could not rise again. An hour later he was done. Blood flies swarmed about his corpse and carried his ill luck to the living. “His time was past,” her handmaid Irri declared. “No man should live longer than his teeth.” The others agreed. Dany bid them kill the weakest of their dying horses, so the dead man might go mounted into the night lands.

Two nights later, it was an infant girl who perished. Her mother’s anguished wailing lasted all day, but there was nothing to be done. The child had been too young to ride, poor thing. Not for her the endless black grasses of the night lands; she must be born again. – Daenerys I ACOK

She also leads them and keeps them together by showing that she cares about them. She doesn’t see herself above her people, and because of this, she starves with them and cares for them:

Dany hungered and thirsted with the rest of them. The milk in her breasts dried up, her nipples cracked and bled, and the flesh fell away from her day by day until she was lean and hard as a stick, yet it was her dragons she feared for. – Daenerys I ACOK

Doreah took a fever and grew worse with every league they crossed. Her lips and hands broke with blood blisters, her hair came out in clumps, and one evenfall she lacked the strength to mount her horse. Jhogo said they must leave her or bind her to her saddle, but Dany remembered a night on the Dothraki sea, when the Lysene girl had taught her secrets so that Drogo might love her more. She gave Doreah water from her own skin, cooled her brow with a damp cloth, and held her hand until she died, shivering. Only then would she permit the khalasar to press on. – Daenerys I ACOK

She keeps them alive by being pragmatic, like when she insists in entering the abandoned city, breaking the taboo of the Dothraki against such places because they need food:

Other searchers returned with tales of other fruit trees, hidden behind closed doors in secret gardens. Aggo showed her a courtyard overgrown with twisting vines and tiny green grapes, and Jhogo discovered a well where the water was pure and cold. Yet they found bones too, the skulls of the unburied dead, bleached and broken. “Ghosts,” Irri muttered. “Terrible ghosts. We must not stay here, Khaleesi, this is their place.”

“I fear no ghosts. Dragons are more powerful than ghosts.” And figs are more important. – Daenerys I ACOK

And she saves her people by making the sensible choice of sending her bloodriders in different directions to find a way out of the desert:

“What shall we seek, Khaleesi?” asked Jhogo.

“Whatever there is,” Dany answered. “Seek for other cities, living and dead. Seek for caravans and people. Seek for rivers and lakes and the great salt sea. Find how far this waste extends before us, and what lies on the other side. When I leave this place, I do not mean to strike out blind again. I will know where I am bound, and how best to get there.” – Daenerys I ACOK

All of these actions enabled her to keep her khalasar together and keep their loyalty. And after many deaths and suffering, they finally get to Qarth.

But when they arrive in Qarth, there are more challenges. Dany thinks that she’ll find something in the city:

The Bleeding Star led me to Qarth for a purpose. Here I will find what I need, if I have the strength to take what is offered, and the wisdom to avoid the traps and snares. If the gods mean for me to conquer, they will provide, they will send me a sign, and if not … if not … – Daenerys II ACOK

And this quote establishes Dany’s arc in this book very well, because this part of her story is a test for her as a leader, and she learns some important lessons. She has to escape different deceptions, and Dany is careful about that. Even with all their flatteries, she doesn’t trust Xaro and Pyat Pree, and takes precautions against them:

“I do not understand her.” Pyat and Xaro had showered Dany with promises from the moment they first glimpsed her dragons, declaring themselves her loyal servants in all things, but from Quaithe she had gotten only the rare cryptic word. And it disturbed her that she had never seen the woman’s face. Remember Mirri Maz Duur, she told herself. Remember treachery. She turned to her bloodriders. “We will keep our own watch so long as we are here. See that no one enters this wing of the palace without my leave, and take care that the dragons are always well guarded.”

“It shall be done, Khaleesi,” Aggo said.

“We have seen only the parts of Qarth that Pyat Pree wished us to see,” she went on. “Rakharo, go forth and look on the rest, and tell me what you find. Take good men with you—and women, to go places where men are forbidden.”

“As you say, I do, blood of my blood,” said Rakharo. – Daenerys II ACOK

Later, Dany also escapes treachery by refusing to fall for Xaro’s bad deal (he had offered her 30 ships for one dragon):

“I am trying to set a price on one of the three living dragons in the world.“ Dany smiled at him sweetly. "It seems to me that one-third of all the ships in the world would be fair.” – Daenerys V ACOK

She also sends Jorah to find out about news from Westeros and to find ships that could take them:

“Ser Jorah, find the docks and see what manner of ships lay at anchor. It has been half a year since I last heard tidings from the Seven Kingdoms. Perhaps the gods will have blown some good captain here from Westeros with a ship to carry us home.”

The knight frowned. “That would be no kindness. The Usurper will kill you, sure as sunrise.” Mormont hooked his thumbs through his swordbelt. “My place is here at your side.”

“Jhogo can guard me as well. You have more languages than my bloodriders, and the Dothraki mistrust the sea and those who sail her. Only you can serve me in this. Go among the ships and speak to the crews, learn where they are from and where they are bound and what manner of men command them.” – Daenerys II ACOK

The interesting thing here is that Dany can see the strengths in each of her men and can use them accordingly. She knows that Ser Jorah is the most adequate person to entrust this task to, and this shows her abilities as a leader, because a leader must know the people under her command.

Dany is not only trying to escape deception, but she’s also trying to get help to conquer Westeros. She tries to bribe the Pureborn and follow Qartheen traditions, but it doesn’t work. Soon, Dany starts to realize that she won’t find help to conquer Westeros as a beggar:

Yet even crowned, I am a beggar still, Dany thought. I have become the most splendid beggar in the world, but a beggar all the same. She hated it, as her brother must have. All those years of running from city to city one step ahead of the Usurper’s knives, pleading for help from archons and princes and magisters, buying our food with flattery. He must have known how they mocked him. Small wonder he turned so angry and bitter. In the end it had driven him mad. It will do the same to me if I let it. Part of her would have liked nothing more than to lead her people back to Vaes Tolorro, and make the dead city bloom. No, that is defeat. I have something Viserys never had. I have the dragons. The dragons are all the difference. – Daenerys III ACOK

Qarth is also important for Dany’s arc as a leader because it’s a place of temptation. Qarth is a city filled with splendors: it’s beautiful, it has magic, it’s wealthy. And both Xaro and Pyat Pree are offering them to Dany. If she stays with Pyat Pree, she will have sorceries and magical knowledge at her disposal. If she stays with Xaro, she will be a wealthy woman for the rest of her life. But if she does that, she will have to stay in Qarth forever and will never achieve her true desire, to go home to Westeros. This is a moment in her arc in which Dany has to decide what she truly wants: does she want a life of luxury or does she want to pursue a greater destiny for herself? In the end, Dany decides to leave Qarth and make her own path.

In this book, Dany has successfully led her people through the desert through strength, pragmatism and determination, and has escaped Qarth because of her cleverness. She has also finally decided what she wants for herself:

Three heads has the dragon, Dany thought, wondering. “I shall tell my people to make ready to depart at once. But the ships that bring me home must bear different names.”

“As you wish,” said Arstan. “What names would you prefer?”

“Vhagar,” Daenerys told him. “Meraxes. And Balerion. Paint the names on their hulls in golden letters three feet high, Arstan. I want every man who sees them to know the dragons are returned.” – Daenerys V ACOK

SHAPING THE WORLD

The third and fifth book are the ones in which Dany starts to more actively shape the world around her. While in the first two books, Dany is leading through her strength, adaptation to culture, instinct and pragmatism, now she finally starts to deal with more complex issues. She no longer leads a small khalasar – she has to deal with big armies and thousands of different and diverse people. She’s no longer just defying Dothraki tradition – she is fighting against a continent wide system of slavery. She has to deal with military strategy, food, trade, diplomacy, peace and war, and this is the moment in which Dany grows the most, reflects on what is means to be a ruler, and on what it means to be a revolutionary.

A STORM OF SWORDS

In this book, we see both Dany’s brilliance and inexperience. She has huge victories, but also makes huge mistakes.

The book starts with Dany going to Illyrio, until Jorah points out that going there without an army would be risky. He convinces Dany to go to Astapor to buy the Unsullied. There, she sees the horrors of slavery and decides to start her liberation of the slaves.

In each of the cities, Dany makes brilliant plans. In Astapor, Dany pretends that she doesn’t speak Valyrian, at Ser Jorah’s suggestion, to get to hear what Kraznis doesn’t want her to hear. But she also sets in motion a plan that she creates all on her own: she asks Jorah how Astapor is defended, and later asks Missandei if the things Kraznis told her were true, to get more information before she acts. Then, she uses a Qartheen dress look more wealthy, and successfully negotiates with the slavers, managing to buy all of the Unsullied so that her plan can work. She refuses to let Ser Barristan undermine her, ordering him to be taken away from her presence when he speaks out of turn. While setting her plan in motion, she dresses in Dothraki clothes and puts the weakest of her people inside the column, with the warriors outside, in order to appear more intimidating. And before she turns on the masters, she makes sure to tell the Unsullied that she has paid for them, and they belong to her now, so that they know they no longer have to be loyal to the Astapori masters. It was a very risky plan, and if it failed, Dany and all of her people would have died. But Dany took all the steps necessary for it to be a success.

In Yunkai, she tells the sellswords that she wants answers to her offers on the next day, gives the Second Sons wine to get them drunk, and tells the Yukish envoy that they have three days to think. Then, she organizes a surprise attack, defeating the sellsword companies almost with no bloodshed and with even fewer losses on her side.

In Meereen, Dany doesn’t have surprise on her side, since the Meereenese have come to expect an attack and hid behind their walls. She understands the necessity of facing Meereen’s champion (“If I ignore this any longer, my own people will think me weak” – Daenerys V ASOS), but carefully chooses who will face this champion:

Aggo, Jhogo, and Rakharo were brave warriors, but they were young, and too valuable to risk. They kept her khalasar together, and were her best scouts too. - Daenerys V ASOS

“It’s his city I want, not his meager manhood.” She was growing angry, however. If I ignore this any longer, my own people will think me weak. Yet who could she send? She needed Daario as much as she did her bloodriders. Without the flamboyant Tyroshi, she had no hold on the Stormcrows, many of whom had been followers of Prendahl na Ghezn and Sallor the Bald. - Daenerys V ASOS

Once again, Dany shows herself as a capable leader, one that understands the importance and strengths of each men under her command. So she ends up sending Belwas, reasoning that:

“Strong Belwas was a slave here in the fighting pits. If this highborn Oznak should fall to such the Great Masters will be shamed, while if he wins … well, it is a poor victory for one so noble, one that Meereen can take no pride in.” And unlike Ser Jorah, Daario, Brown Ben, and her three bloodriders, the eunuch did not lead troops, plan battles, or give her counsel. He does nothing but eat and boast and bellow at Arstan. Belwas was the man she could most easily spare. And it was time she learned what sort of protector Magister Illyrio had sent her. – Daenerys V ASOS

She also takes care of Belwas, which is good to show her people that she cares about them. But this is not enough to take the city, of course. The Meereenese burnt all the trees, so Dany can’t build siege weapons. There are heads of harpies above the gates to pour boiling oil, and she doesn’t have enough food to feed her people (and can’t take it from land, since the slavers burned the trees). Her advisors tell her to leave Meereen behind and go to Westeros, and let her people starve on the march. But Dany refuses to leave her people to die, and she refuses to unnecessarily waste the lives of the Unsullied to assault the walls under attack of boiling oil. Instead, Dany shows her resourcefulness – she makes siege weapons out of the ships that Illyrio sent her, and sends soldiers to strike the chains of the slaves in the pits so they could also help her take the city from within.

Dany proves herself to be very intelligent, showing creativeness, resourcefulness, understanding of the different people that serve her and how each can be useful for her, understanding of the need to keep up appearances and manipulate people’s perceptions, and showing that she cares for her people. But intelligence alone isn’t enough. This book is also the one in which we see how her naivety, inexperience and lack of education impacts badly on her, and leads her to make mistakes.

In Astapor, she doesn’t leave any army behind to protect the city. Because of that, the council that she left governing is easily overthrown by the Butcher King. In Yunkai, she doesn’t really conquer the city, and leaves the masters still in power. Then, as soon as she leaves, the masters enslave everyone again. These mistakes also have serious consequences for Dany’s future reign in Meereen: because of them, Dany will later have to deal with Astapori refugees, a plague, and with the city of Yunkai making alliances against her and besieging her city.

These are mistakes that show her inexperience, and lack of formal education, but they also show that Dany had bad advisors: both Jorah and Barristan don’t really care about Dany’s anti-slavery campaign. They constantly tell her that she has nothing to gain here, and that she should just go to Westeros. Because none of them is interested in ending slavery, they don’t warn Dany about the mistakes that she is making: they don’t advise her to leave an army in Astapor, and they don’t tell her what’s going to happen when she leaves Yunkai. Both of them are more educated and experienced than her, and yet they tell her nothing.

Another thing that has consequences in the future is the question of bad faith. Dany does care about being honorable and upholding certain deals:

Strong Belwas drew his arakh. “Strong Belwas will give his ugly tongue to the little queen, if she likes.”

“No, Belwas. I have given these men my safe conduct.” – Daenerys IV ASOS

But at the same time, Dany’s battle plans in Astapor and Yunkai both involved deceit, and she also uses her dragons to intimidate an envoy. This deceit was necessary, though: Dany starts with no army, and she’s at a disadvantage when dealing with the slavers. It was certainly the right thing to do, and the best she could do in her circumstances. But of course, it will still have consequences in the future, during her efforts to make peace, because the slavers don’t trust her:

“Ah, there is the thorn in the bower, my queen,” said Hizdahr zo Loraq. “Sad to say, Yunkai has no faith in your promises. They keep plucking the same string on the harp, about some envoy that your dragons set on fire.”

“Only his tokar was burned,” said Dany scornfully.

“Be that as it may, they do not trust you. The men of New Ghis feel the same. Words are wind, as you yourself have so oft said. No words of yours will secure this peace for Meereen. Your foes require deeds. They would see us wed, and they would see me crowned as king, to rule beside you.” – Daenerys VI ADWD

Daenerys can’t unmake her mistakes. But thankfully, she learns from them. She refuses to leave Meereen behind, like she did in Astapor and Yunkai. And later in the next book, Dany is very mindful of what might happen to her city if she takes her army away, showing that she learned from her mistake in Astapor:

“I know that the Mother of Dragons will not abandon us in our hour of peril. Lend us your Unsullied to defend our walls.”

And if I do, who will defend my walls? – Daenerys III ADWD

Westeros. Home. But if she left, what would happen to her city? - Daenerys III ADWD

“Meet the foe,” she echoed, “with the freedmen you’ve called half-trained and unblooded.”

“We were all unblooded once, Your Grace. The Unsullied will help stiffen them. If I had five hundred knights …”

“Or five. And if I give you the Unsullied, I will have no one but the Brazen Beasts to hold Meereen.” When Ser Barristan did not dispute her, Dany closed her eyes. Gods, she prayed, you took Khal Drogo, who was my sun-and-stars. You took our valiant son before he drew a breath. You have had your blood of me. Help me now, I pray you. Give me the wisdom to see the path ahead and the strength to do what I must to keep my children safe. - Daenerys V ADWD

She also understands her mistakes in leaving Yunkai untaken and leaving the masters in power:

His new Unsullied are an obscene jape. “King Cleon would be wise to tend his own gardens and let the Yunkai'i tend theirs.” It was not that Dany harbored any love for Yunkai. She was coming to regret leaving the Yellow City untaken after defeating its army in the field. The Wise Masters had returned to slaving as soon as she moved on, and were busy raising levies, hiring sellswords, and making alliances against her. – Daenerys I ADWD

Overall, I think this book is great to show us just how smart Dany is: she seeks different sources of information in Astapor, listens to Ser Barristan’s lessons in military matters, makes brilliant plans that minimize bloodshed, knows her men and how to use each of them, and punishes rapists and murderers in her army after the sack of Meereen. But this book also strips Dany of her initial naivety, and she realizes that conquering and ruling are not the same thing. She realizes that she needs experience. And we see, once again, one of Dany’s greatest qualities: her self-reflection and willingness to learn. She decides to stay, learn how to be a ruler and take responsibility for her actions.

A DANCE WITH DRAGONS

ASOS is, in my opinion, the book in which Dany makes the most mistakes, leading to the consequences that I already described. But I also think that we shouldn’t look at her mistakes in ASOS and say that this means that Dany is an awful ruler. Because it’s more than understandable why she makes these mistakes. She has no education or experience. It would be unrealistic if she knew everything she had to do from the start.

So in ADWD, Dany has to deal with the mistakes she has already made, because she can’t unmake them, she can’t go back in time to fix them. She also has to deal with a lot of situations that are completely out of her control. In my opinion, while Dany made big mistakes in Astapor and Yunkai, she dealt very well with the situation in Meereen, considering her circumstances. So let’s dive into it. Meereen’s storyline is very complex, so I’ll deal with different aspects of it in different sections.

  • Economy

People criticize Daenerys for several things: because “she destroyed the economy”, because “she should have a plan before she took the city to stop the economy from collapsing” and “she didn’t do anything to establish a new economy without slavery”. So let’s address these criticisms.

“She destroyed the economy”

Let’s look at everything we know about Meereen’s economy:

Their main export are slaves. Astapor produces soldiers, Yunkai produces bed slaves, and Meereen produces bedslaves, teachers and artisans.

Aside from slaves, Meereen also has olives, salt, wine and copper. In the hinterlands, slaves grow wheat and olives, herd sheep and goats, and mine salt and copper. But even though Meereen produces other things beyond slaves, they are not enough to sustain the economy, and Meereen’s economy is based mostly on slavery:

Without slaves, Meereen had little to offer traders. – Daenerys III ADWD

When Dany ends slavery, this means that she no longer has slaves to sell. And the slavers burnt the olive trees and the best grape arbors before Dany came into the city to stop her from building siege weapons. Copper is not a very valuable metal and Meereen’s wine is of an inferior vintage.

These things aren’t Dany’s fault. Meereen didn’t have a lot of things to trade aside from slaves, and she couldn’t stop the masters from burning the olive trees and the grape arbors. This means that Meereen’s economy was already very poor (it was rich because of slavery, but poor in other things) before Dany even conquered the city.

And there’s also the fact that Dany is not the kind of person to leave her people behind, so she lets the former slaves from Astapor and Yunkai come with her, which also means that she has more mouths to feed.

If Daenerys wants to end slavery, there’s nothing she can do about the fact that the economy will suffer if she no longer has slaves to sell.

There are also some problems that came with Dany’s mistakes in Yunkai and Astapor. The fact that Dany didn’t take the masters out of power in Yunkai meant that, as soon as Dany left, they reenslaved people, and decided to attack Dany in Meereen, putting her city under siege. The Yunkish army surrounded her city from land, and Qartheen ships closed the bay, so she can’t get trade, and fishers can’t go into the bay. This is partly because of Dany’s mistakes, because she left the masters of Yunkai in power. But as I’ve said, Dany can’t go back in time to fix those mistakes, she can only deal with the consequences. And Dany would have to face opposition no matter what she did. The powers of Essos would not simply accept Dany freeing their slaves and ruining their economy, and Dany also poses a symbolical threat. So most likely, the economy of the city would suffer because of the war against the slavers, no matter what Dany did.

Ending slavery means disrupting the economy, there’s no way around it.

“She should have a plan before she took the city to stop the economy from collapsing”

I’ve seen people suggest that Dany should have ended slavery gradually, or that she should have waited to end slavery, so that she could first build a new economy, and only later free the slaves. But there are practical and ethical problems with these suggestions.

Dany used the help of the slaves to take the city. While Dany was trying to take the city from the outside, the slaves rose in revolt from the inside. Dany even sends part of her men to strike off the chains of the slaves in the fighting pits. After taking the city with their help, Dany can’t just tell the slaves “I’m not going to free you because of the economy, so you will have to wait”. If she did that, she would turn the slaves against her, and she would have both slaves and slavers trying to overthrow her. And if she did wait to free the slaves, she would probably have to compromise more with the slavers to be able to rule, and this would make it impossible for her to free the slaves later.

Besides, “ending slavery gradually” is just inhumane. Take into consideration that every day, slaves are being raped, tortured, mutilated and overworked. If you think that Daenerys should have ended slavery gradually, so that she could preserve the economy and end slavery “peacefully”, that only means that you care more about the lives of the slavers and their livelihood than you care about the slaves.

“She didn’t do anything to establish a new economy without slavery”

Another baseless accusation. Dany does a lot to rebuild Meereen’s economy. She plants beans, grapes, olives and wheat. She sends her khalasar to conquer the hinterlands and free the slaves there, and these former slaves are also planting and bringing their crops to Meereen. The Green Grace had told Dany that the soil of Meereen became infertile after the wars with the Valyrians, so she starts to build a ditch to bring water to the plantations, showing how Dany is resourceful and how she is thinking in the long term, working on the infrastructure of the city to make it agriculturally independent. She also sends Daario to Lhazar, to reopen the overland trade routes and bring grains into the city. She negotiates with Xaro, hoping to trade the few things that Meereen has to offer. And when the city is put under siege, Dany compromises and marries Hizdahr, so that the siege can be lifted and she can have trade again. She also has to deal with things like guilds of artisans, that don’t want to allow freedmen into their business, so Dany has to demand that they open their rolls to the freedmen.

But even all of those things are not enough, because some things are simply impossible. She can’t make crops grow overnight and she doesn’t have magical wagons to fly over the siege lines and deliver trade into her city. No matter how good a ruler is, these things are just not possible. Rebuilding an economy after ending slavery is extremely difficult and takes a long time, and GRRM wrote a very realistic story with Daenerys. You can’t expect everything to be perfect after only a few months of Daenerys ruling. But her efforts here show that she’s a good and responsible ruler, and did everything she could to rebuild Meeren’s economy.

  • The war against Yunkai and the question of peace and war

When Dany conquers Meereen, she has seen the destruction that the war caused. Her people are starving, and she has learned that she won’t make things right just by freeing slaves and moving on from place to place. To make matters worse, she has to deal with the terrorist organization The Sons of the Harpy, that are killing freedmen, and even started killing her own soldiers. So it’s no surprise that with all of the slaughter and bloodshed, she wants peace more than anything.

So Dany starts making compromises with the slavers. These compromises involve different things: she needs to marry Hizdahr, a powerful men who comes from one of the Great Master’s families; she has to give indemnity in gold and gemstones to the slavers of Yunkai, as a compensation for disrupting the slave trade; she has to allow slavery to return outside Meereen; she has to reopen the fighting pits; and she has to allow slavers from outside to bring their slaves into Meereen.

Many people accuse Dany of being stupid and naive for believing in Hizdahr and the peace, and not seeing that Hizdahr is probably allied with the Sons of the Harpy. But this criticism is unfounded, because Dany does see that he’s probably one of them:

“Can you?” Dany studied his eyes. “Why should the Sons of the Harpy lay down their knives for you? Are you one of them?”

“No.”

“Would you tell me if you were?”

He laughed. “No.” - Daenerys IV ADWD

Dany makes these compromises not because she’s naive, but because at her core, she is someone who doesn’t like war and conflicts. But there are also practical reasons: after chaining her dragons, Dany doesn’t have enough military power to defy the masters. But that doesn’t mean that Dany just meekly accepts anything. She insists on the freedom of the people in Meereen, she insists in certain rules for the fighting pits (like not allowing children, slaves, and not allowing thieves and debtors to be forced to fight), she demands that the guilds of Meereen allow freedmen, and she trains her own soldier companies, because she wants to be prepared to defend her city:

He was wrong in that, she hoped. The freedmen had been a rabble once, but she had organized the men of fighting age into companies and commanded Grey Worm to make them into soldiers. – Daenerys III ADWD

She also has Ser Barristan training some boys to be knights.

With these actions, Dany achieves a shaky peace with Yunkai, and she gets the Sons of the Harpy to stop attacking. She prepares her city in the case of a war. She also manages to make her conditions on who fights in the pits, and to make changes in the laws of Meereen, like in the case of the guilds. I think it’s important to acknowledge that Dany’s course of action in Meereen was a sensible one, and she did achieve some small victories.

But this plot isn’t just about seeing just how much Dany can accomplish as a ruler. It’s also meant for her to reflect and learn about what peace and war mean. She starts the books as someone who was appalled by the costs of war, and tries everything she can to get peace. But as time goes, she realizes that her merciful path has also caused problems. One example is when she reflects about certain mistakes that she made, like leaving the slave masters in power:

She had not forgotten the slave children the Great Masters had nailed up along the road from Yunkai. They had numbered one hundred sixty-three, a child every mile, nailed to mileposts with one arm outstretched to point her way. After Meereen had fallen, Dany had nailed up a like number of Great Masters. Swarms of flies had attended their slow dying, and the stench had lingered long in the plaza. Yet some days she feared that she had not gone far enough. These Meereenese were a sly and stubborn people who resisted her at every turn. They had freed their slaves, yes … only to hire them back as servants at wages so meagre that most could scarce afford to eat. Those too old or young to be of use had been cast into the streets, along with the infirm and the crippled. And still the Great Masters gathered atop their lofty pyramids to complain of how the dragon queen had filled their noble city with hordes of unwashed beggars, thieves, and whores. – Daenerys I ADWD

She starts to question the costs of peace as well:

“There may be another choice. The Yunkai'i can be persuaded to allow all your freedmen to remain free, I believe, if Your Worship will agree that the Yellow City may trade and train slaves unmolested from this day forth. No more blood need flow.”

“Save for the blood of those slaves that the Yunkai'i will trade and train,” Dany said, but she recognized the truth in his words even so. It may be that is the best end we can hope for. – Daenerys IV ADWD

“His Grace is dreaming, but I cannot sleep. On the morrow I must bathe in blood. The price of peace.” – Daenerys VIII

The Brazen Beasts did as they were bid. Dany watched them at their work. “Those bearers were slaves before I came. I made them free. Yet that palanquin is no lighter.”

“True,” said Hizdahr, “but those men are paid to bear its weight now. Before you came, that man who fell would have an overseer standing over him, stripping the skin off his back with a whip. Instead he is being given aid.”

It was true. A Brazen Beast in a boar mask had offered the litter bearer a skin of water. “I suppose I must be thankful for small victories,” the queen said. – Daenerys IX ADWD

They stamped their feet and slapped their bellies and shouted, “Mhysa, Mhysa, Mhysa,” until the whole pit seemed to tremble. Dany let the sound wash over her. I am not your mother, she might have shouted, back, I am the mother of your slaves, of every boy who ever died upon these sands whilst you gorged on honeyed locusts. – Daenerys IX ADWD

She also realizes that this peace isn’t truly sustainable, because she’s in the hands of the slavers:

Dany scarce touched a bite. This is peace, she told herself. This is what I wanted, what I worked for, this is why I married Hizdahr. So why does it taste so much like defeat?

“It is only for a little while more, my love,” Hizdahr had assured her. “The Yunkai'i will soon be gone, and their allies and hirelings with them. We shall have all we desired. Peace, food, trade. Our port is open once again, and ships are being permitted to come and go.”

“They are permitting that, yes,” she had replied, “but their warships remain. They can close their fingers around our throat again whenever they wish. They have opened a slave market within sight of my walls!” – Daenerys VIII ADWD

Dany (rightfully) distrusts the peace, and tries to prepare herself for an eventual attack, by using her wits to make the sellswords change sides once again:

No, she thought, you are too honest and too honorable. “If not, the Yunkai'i employ three other companies.”

“Rogues and cutthroats, scum of a hundred battlefields,” Ser Barristan warned, “with captains full as treacherous as Plumm.”

“I am only a young girl and know little of such things, but it seems to me that we want them to be treacherous. Once, you’ll recall, I convinced the Second Sons and Stormcrows to join us.”

“If Your Grace wishes a privy word with Gylo Rhegan or the Tattered Prince, I could bring them up to your apartments.”

“This is not the time. Too many eyes, too many ears. Their absence would be noted even if you could separate them discreetly from the Yunkai'i. We must find some quieter way of reaching out to them … not tonight, but soon.”

“As you command. Though I fear this is not a task for which I am well suited. In King’s Landing work of this sort was left to Lord Littlefinger or the Spider. We old knights are simple men, only good for fighting.” He patted his sword hilt.

“Our prisoners,” suggested Dany. “The Westerosi who came over from the Windblown with the three Dornishmen. We still have them in cells, do we not? Use them.”

“Free them, you mean? Is that wise? They were sent here to worm their way into your trust, so they might betray Your Grace at the first chance.”

“Then they failed. I do not trust them. I will never trust them.” If truth be told, Dany was forgetting how to trust. “We can still use them. One was a woman. Meris. Send her back, as a … a gesture of my regard. If their captain is a clever man, he will understand.”

“The woman is the worst of all.”

“All the better.” Dany considered a moment. “We should sound out the Long Lances too. And the Company of the Cat.”

“Bloodbeard.” Ser Barristan’s frown deepened. “If it please Your Grace, we want no part of him. Your Grace is too young to remember the Ninepenny Kings, but this Bloodbeard is cut from the same savage cloth. There is no honor in him, only hunger … for gold, for glory, for blood.”

“You know more of such men than me, ser.” If Bloodbeard might be truly the most dishonorable and greedy of the sellswords, he might be the easiest to sway, but she was loath to go against Ser Barristan’s counsel in such matters. “Do as you think best. But do it soon. If Hizdahr’s peace should break, I want to be ready. I do not trust the slavers.” I do not trust my husband. “They will turn on us at the first sign of weakness.”

“The Yunkai'i grow weaker as well. The bloody flux has taken hold amongst the Tolosi, it is said, and spread across the river to the third Ghiscari legion.”

The pale mare. Daenerys sighed. Quaithe warned me of the pale mare’s coming. She told me of the Dornish prince as well, the sun’s son. She told me much and more, but all in riddles. “I cannot rely on plague to save me from my enemies. Set Pretty Meris free. At once.” – Daenerys VIII ADWD

She starts to see that peace is not ideal like she had thought. And she starts to reflect if this peace is really worth it, and comes to the conclusion that it isn’t:

“One will die, or the other will,” said Dany. “And the one who lives will die some other day. This was a mistake.”

“Strong Belwas ate too many locusts.” There was a queasy look on Belwas’s broad brown face. “Strong Belwas needs milk.”

Hizdahr ignored the eunuch. “Magnificence, the people of Meereen have come to celebrate our union. You heard them cheering you. Do not cast away their love.”

“It was my floppy ears they cheered, not me. Take me from this abbatoir, husband.” – Daenerys IX ADWD

This is as much about Dany reclaiming her identity as it is about her changing her political views. A peace that means that she has to give indemnity to slavers, watch people fight to death, and let slavery continue is no true peace, because thousands and thousands of people will continue suffering the violence of slavery. And Dany doesn’t want to be the kind of ruler that stands by while injustice happens. So by the end of ADWD, she finally accepts fire and blood, which is necessary if she wants to end slavery once and for all.

I think these reflections are necessary for Dany’s learning. She needs to know when compromises are worth or not. She needs to learn how to be more decisive to achieve the goals she has of social change. She needs to learn when to seek peace, and when to use Fire and Blood.

  • The question of taking the wealth of the slave masters

I’ve seen many people in the fandom saying that Dany should have taken the wealth of the slavers. I agree with that. If Dany had taken their wealth, they would no longer be able to finance an opposition against her. She could redistribute their wealth to the former slaves, helping to minimize inequality, and she could have used it to buy sellswords to fight for her. This way, she wouldn’t have to compromise as much as she did. On the other hand, I don’t think this would solve all of her problems. Because, as I said, the economy was mostly based on slavery. It would still take time to rebuild the economy and base it on something else. It would take time for Meereen to become agriculturally independent and for Meereen to start producing new products for trade.

And it’s understandable why Dany doesn’t do this. First, because she has no experience, and she needs to learn. It would make no sense to write a story about Dany learning if she already knows everything she has to do from the start. Also, because, as pointed out in the previous sections, Dany is trying to be moderate and conciliatory. And as someone who is highborn, Dany doesn’t really believe in the idea of depriving the nobility of what they possess, even if she’s siding with the oppressed. Taking the nobility’s wealth is something that is very against everything Dany has been taught her entire life. So at the beginning of the story, Dany doesn’t want to be too radical. But that doesn’t mean she’s not smart and doesn’t think about it. This is actually something that Dany herself does, even though she doesn’t do it enough:

That brought a smile to the Shavepate’s face. “It will be done,” he said, “but Your Radiance should know that the Great Masters of Zhak and Merreq are making preparations to quit their pyramids and leave the city.”

Daenerys was sick unto death of Zhak and Merreq; she was sick of all the Mereenese, great and small alike. “Let them go, but see that they take no more than the clothes upon their backs. Make certain that all their gold remains here with us. Their stores of food as well.” – Daenerys II ADWD

And later, Daario too suggests it to her:

“You are fighting shadows when you should be fighting the men who cast them,” Daario went on. “Kill them all and take their treasures, I say. Whisper the command, and your Daario will make you a pile of their heads taller than this pyramid.”

“If I knew who they were—”

“Zhak and Pahl and Merreq. Them, and all the rest. The Great Masters. Who else would it be?”

He is as bold as he is bloody. “We have no proof this is their work. Would you have me slaughter my own subjects?” – Daenerys IV ADWD

Dany is reluctant. She’s smart enough to realize that she needs to take the wealth of the masters, but she’s not willing to go too far (and she’s even less willing to accept Daario’s violent idea). But if the ending of ADWD is any indication, Dany has changed her stance, and won’t be indecisive anymore.

  • Conflicting interests within the city

Even though I think the compromises and the peace were a mistake, I think it’s pointless to look at what Dany should have done. We need to look at what she decided to do. Dany decided to strive for peace, so I think that we should look at how she worked to achieve that.

At the start of Dany’s reign, slaves and slavers want different things, and there are many problems that arose with the sack: the slavers want punishment for the crimes during the sack, and the slaves want the masters punished for their past crimes against them. In face of this, Dany chooses conciliation, pardoning the crimes during the sack and the crimes the slavers committed before she took the city, not only out of clemency, but also out of pragmatism:

A former slave came, to accuse a certain noble of the Zhak. The man had recently taken to wife a freedwoman who had been the noble’s bedwarmer before the city fell. The noble had taken her maidenhood, used her for his pleasure, and gotten her with child. Her new husband wanted the noble gelded for the crime of rape, and he wanted a purse of gold as well, to pay him for raising the noble’s bastard as his own. Dany granted him the gold, but not the gelding. “When he lay with her, your wife was his property, to do with as he would. By law, there was no rape.” Her decision did not please him, she could see, but if she gelded every man who ever forced a bedslave, she would soon rule a city of eunuchs.

A boy came, younger than Dany, slight and scarred, dressed up in a frayed grey tokar trailing silver fringe. His voice broke when he told of how two of his father’s household slaves had risen up the night the gate broke. One had slain his father, the other his elder brother. Both had raped his mother before killing her as well. The boy had escaped with no more than the scar upon his face, but one of the murderers was still living in his father’s house, and the other had joined the queen’s soldiers as one of the Mother’s Men. He wanted them both hanged.

I am queen over a city built on dust and death. Dany had no choice but to deny him. She had declared a blanket pardon for all crimes committed during the sack. Nor would she punish slaves for rising up against their masters. – Daenerys I ADWD

After the sack of Meereen, Dany had punished rapists and murderers amongst her own soldiers:

She had decreed that murderers were to be hanged, that looters were to lose a hand, and rapists their manhood. Eight killers swung from the walls, and the Unsullied had filled a bushel basket with bloody hands and soft red worms, but Meereen was calm again. - Daenerys VI ASOS

But in Meereen, she can’t control what the slaves do while rising against their masters, and punishing crimes committed during the sack would be impractical and give rise to lots of conflicts and anger from the former slaves against her. Similarly, punishing the former masters would be impractical as well. This decision shows Dany’s pragmatism, and it was important for keeping some semblance of peace in Meereen.

She also rules that a rich woman that lost her house cannot have it back, but that she can have back her jewels and clothes. I’ve seen many people criticize Dany for it, but the intention was clear and consistent with Dany’s intentions in Meereen. Dany tries to be conciliatory, granting the woman her clothes and jewels, but denying her the house, because the alternative would mean that the former slaves occupying the house would be homeless.

Another instance in which we can see Dany being conciliatory is how she treats the problem of the guilds of artisans in Meereen:

Her sleepless night soon made itself felt. Before long she was fighting off a yawn as Reznak prattled about the craftsmen's guilds. The stonemasons were wroth with her, it seemed. The bricklayers as well. Certain former slaves were carving stone and laying bricks, stealing work from guild journeymen and masters alike. “The freedmen work too cheaply, Magnificence,” Reznak said. “Some call themselves journeymen, or even masters, titles that belong by rights only to the craftsmen of the guilds. The masons and the bricklayers do respectfully petition Your Worship to uphold their ancient rights and customs.”
