Dany tries to be conciliatory, granting the woman her clothes and jewels, but denying her the house, because the alternative would mean that the former slaves occupying the house would be homeless.

Another instance in which we can see Dany being conciliatory is how she treats the problem of the guilds of artisans in Meereen:

Her sleepless night soon made itself felt. Before long she was fighting off a yawn as Reznak prattled about the craftsmen's guilds. The stonemasons were wroth with her, it seemed. The bricklayers as well. Certain former slaves were carving stone and laying bricks, stealing work from guild journeymen and masters alike. “The freedmen work too cheaply, Magnificence,” Reznak said. “Some call themselves journeymen, or even masters, titles that belong by rights only to the craftsmen of the guilds. The masons and the bricklayers do respectfully petition Your Worship to uphold their ancient rights and customs.”

“The freedmen work cheaply because they are hungry,” Dany pointed out. “If I forbid them to carve stone or lay bricks, the chandlers, the weavers, and the goldsmiths will soon be at my gates asking that they be excluded from those trades as well.” She considered a moment. “Let it be written that henceforth only guild members shall be permitted to name themselves journeymen or masters … provided the guilds open their rolls to any freedman who can demonstrate the requisite skills.” – Daenerys II ADWD

Dany manages to partially pacify the guild members, saying that only them could name themselves journeymen or masters, while also keeping the freedmen in their trades and demanding that they have a place in the guilds.

To keep the peace, Dany also adapts to Meereenese culture and traditions. She speaks their language:

A small, damp man, he smelled as if he had bathed in perfume and spoke a bastard form of High Valyrian, much corrupted and flavored with a thick Ghiscari growl.

“You are kind to say so,” Dany answered, in the same tongue. – Daenerys I ADWD

She wears the tokar, even though she understands what the garment symbolizes:

Even wound properly, the tokar required its wearer to hold it in place with the left hand. Walking in a tokar demanded small, mincing steps and exquisite balance, lest one tread upon those heavy trailing fringes. It was not a garment meant for any man who had to work. The tokar was a master’s garment, a sign of wealth and power.

Dany had wanted to ban the tokar when she took Meereen, but her advisors had convinced her otherwise. “The Mother of Dragons must don the tokar or be forever hated,” warned the Green Grace, Galazza Galare. “In the wools of Westeros or a gown of Myrish lace, Your Radiance shall forever remain a stranger amongst us, a grotesque outlander, a barbarian conqueror. Meereen’s queen must be a lady of Old Ghis.” Brown Ben Plumm, the captain of the Second Sons, had put it more succinctly. “Man wants to be the king o’ the rabbits, he best wear a pair o’ floppy ears.” – Daenerys I ADWD

This shows that Dany understands both pros and cons of wearing the tokar. She understands that the garment is a symbol of power. But as someone who’s seeking peace, Dany chooses to wear it to be conciliatory.

Another thing that she does is follow the Meereenese marriage rites and religion, but with one exception:

“Magnificence, you do not understand,” protested Reznak. “The washing of the feet is hallowed by tradition. It signifies that you shall be your husband’s handmaid. The wedding garb is fraught with meaning too. The bride is dressed in dark red veils above a tokar of white silk, fringed with baby pearls.”

[…]

A bride price paid in blood. Daenerys was weary of fighting this battle. Even Ser Barristan did not think she could win. “No ruler can make a people good,” Selmy had told her. “Baelor the Blessed prayed and fasted and built the Seven as splendid a temple as any gods could wish for, yet he could not put an end to war and want.” A queen must listen to her people, Dany reminded herself. “After the wedding Hizdahr will be king. Let him reopen the fighting pits if he wishes. I want no part of it.” Let the blood be on his hands, not mine. She rose. “If my husband wishes me to wash his feet, he must first wash mine. I will tell him so this evening.” She wondered how her betrothed would take that. – Daenerys VI ADWD

Dany understands that for the peace, she must follow Meereenese traditions. But she also understands that as a woman in power, she can’t afford to be seen as weak, so she can’t be seen as “her husband’s handmaid”. Once again, Dany tries a conciliatory solution.

Courtesy is also important in keeping the peace, and Dany does her best to be courteous even when she doesn’t like something:

In the afternoon a sculptor came, proposing to replace the head of the great bronze harpy in the Plaza of Purification with one cast in Dany’s image. She denied him with as much courtesy as she could muster. A pike of unprecedented size had been caught in the Skahazadhan, and the fisherman wished to give it to the queen. She admired the fish extravagantly, rewarded the fisherman with a purse of silver, and sent the pike to her kitchens. A coppersmith had fashioned her a suit of burnished rings to wear to war. She accepted it with fulsome thanks; it was lovely to behold, and all that burnished copper would flash prettily in the sun, though if actual battle threatened, she would sooner be clad in steel. Even a young girl who knew nothing of the ways of war knew that. – Daenerys I ADWD

“Your Grace need only ask him. The noble Hizdahr awaits below. Send down to him if that is your pleasure.”

You presume too much, priestess, the queen thought, but she swallowed her anger and made herself smile. “Why not?” She sent for Ser Barristan and told the old knight to bring Hizdahr to her. “It is a long climb. Have the Unsullied help him up.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

He will be safer as a hostage. My captain was not made for peace. Dany could not risk his cutting down Brown Ben Plumm, making mock of Hizdahr before the court, provoking the Yunkai'i, or otherwise upsetting the agreement that she had given up so much to win. Daario was war and woe. Henceforth, she must keep him out of her bed, out of her heart, and out of her. If he did not betray her, he would master her. She did not know which of those she feared the most. – VIII ADWD

Dany isn’t always perfect. When dealing with Quentyn, she laughs at his story but forgets to explain the reason for her laugh in his language. But even though she slips, Dany still makes an effort to be courteous with him:

“Enough,” Daenerys said. “Prince Quentyn has crossed half the world to offer me his gift, I will not have him treated with discourtesy.” She turned to the Dornishmen. “Would that you had come a year ago. I am pledged to wed the noble Hizdahr zo Loraq.” - Daenerys VII ADWD

And later, because of Dany’s courtesy and kindness, he comes to like her and respect her:

Daenerys never laughed. The rest of Meereen might see him as an amusing curiosity, like the exiled Summer Islander King Robert used to keep at King’s Landing, but the queen had always spoken to him gently. – The Spurned Suitor ADWD

All of this shows that Dany is good enough at her courtesies, even if she sometimes slips.

Finally, Dany is not petty and does not treat people with brutality, even when they offend her, and that’s very important, because she needs to avoid being hated (some people will hate her regardless of what she does, because she goes against their interests, but it’s important that Dany shows herself to be a merciful queen):

When she told him, the boy rushed at her, but his feet tangled in his tokar and he went sprawling headlong on the purple marble. Strong Belwas was on him at once. The huge brown eunuch yanked him up one-handed and shook him like a mastiff with a rat. “Enough, Belwas,” Dany called. “Release him.” To the boy she said, “Treasure that tokar, for it saved your life. You are only a boy, so we will forget what happened here. You should do the same.” But as he left the boy looked back over his shoulder, and when she saw his eyes Dany thought, The Harpy has another Son. - Daenerys I ADWD

“We are all dead, then. You gave us death, not freedom.” Ghael leapt to his feet and spat into her face.

Strong Belwas seized him by the shoulder and slammed him down onto the marble so hard that Dany heard Ghael’s teeth crack. The Shavepate would have done worse, but she stopped him.

“Enough,” she said, dabbing at her cheek with the end of her tokar. “No one has ever died from spittle. Take him away.” - Daenerys III ADWD

With all of that, I think Dany actually did a very good job to keep the peace. She is conciliatory, courteous, seeks peaceful solutions, while also trying to gain small victories for the freedmen. She usually tries to find a middle ground. While I do think the peace was a mistake, I think this period in Dany’s story was important for her to learn.

  • Morality

Dany is a very kind person who strives to do good, but there are also moments in which she gets angered over the injustice that she witnesses. Dany didn’t grow up with anyone to teach her about honor and justice, only Viserys. So this means that she sometimes makes mistakes and takes cruel actions.

The first we see is, of course, the crucifixions of 163 slave masters in punishment for crucifying children. I see many people say that Dany doesn’t care about justice, and that this action proves it, because she supposedly crucified people without caring about guilt and innocence. But I wouldn’t say this is exactly true. First, because Dany does not crucify random people. She asks for the leaders of Meereen (Meereen is ruled by a council of masters), the ones most likely to be responsible for the children’s deaths.

“I want your leaders,” Dany told them. “Give them up, and the rest of you shall be spared.” – Daenerys VI ASOS

It’s true that this is still an eye for an eye, and it’s still a cruel punishment. But Dany does start to feel bad for the action, even if she still believes it to be justice:

Dany remembered the horror she had felt when she had seen the Plaza of Punishment in Astapor. I made a horror just as great, but surely they deserved it. Harsh justice is still justice. – Daenerys VI ASOS

But later in the books, Dany shows herself to care about innocence and guilt:

“You are fighting shadows when you should be fighting the men who cast them,” Daario went on. “Kill them all and take their treasures, I say. Whisper the command, and your Daario will make you a pile of their heads taller than this pyramid.”

“If I knew who they were—”

“Zhak and Pahl and Merreq. Them, and all the rest. The Great Masters. Who else would it be?”

He is as bold as he is bloody. “We have no proof this is their work. Would you have me slaughter my own subjects?” – Daenerys IV ADWD

“This we have heard. And yet Your Radiance has found the courage to answer butchery with mercy. You have not harmed any of the noble children you hold as hostage.”

[…]

“These murders are not their doing,” Dany told the Green Grace, feebly. “I am no butcher queen.” – Daenerys IV ADWD

Another controversial action that Dany takes is the torture of the wineseller daughters. This is obviously wrong, but I need to point out that torture is considered a valid method of interrogation in this world. The Night’s Watch does it, Jon considers throwing Janos Slynt in an ice cell to force him to comply and later puts Cregan Karstark in those cells, Jaehaerys tortures people to find out who murdered Rego Draz, the High Sparrow does it, the Arryns have a torturer and the sky cells that serve as psychological torture… I could go on, but I think I’ve made my point. Dany is a product of her society, so she’s not acting any differently from other rulers. There was circumstancial evidence against the wineseller and his daughters. But we can see that Dany does care about innocence:

“It will be done, Your Worship. Would you have me question them sweetly, or sharply?”

“Sweetly, to begin. Hear what tales they tell and what names they give you. It may be they had no part in this.” She hesitated. “Nine, the noble Reznak said. Who else?” – Daenerys II ADWD

She changes her stance when she gets angered about the cruel death of Rylonna Rhee, and orders them to be questioned sharply. But later, Dany does learn from her mistakes:

“If there is a Harpy.” Skahaz was convinced that somewhere in Meereen the Sons of the Harpy had a highborn overlord, a secret general commanding an army of shadows. Dany did not share his belief. The Brazen Beasts had taken dozens of the Harpy’s Sons, and those who had survived their capture had yielded names when questioned sharply … too many names, it seemed to her. It would have been pleasant to think that all the deaths were the work of a single enemy who might be caught and killed, but Dany suspected that the truth was otherwise. My enemies are legion. “Hizdahr zo Loraq is a persuasive man with many friends. And he is wealthy. Perhaps he has bought this peace for us with gold, or convinced the other highborn that our marriage is in their best interests.”

“If he is not the Harpy, he knows him. I can find the truth of that easy enough. Give me your leave to put Hizdahr to the question, and I will bring you a confession.”

“No,” she said. “I do not trust these confessions. You’ve brought me too many of them, all of them worthless.”

“Your Radiance—”

“No, I said.” – Daenerys V ADWD

She realizes that torture is ineffective, and forbids it. Dany is the only ruler in the books to explicitly forbid torture.

I think what all of this shows is that Dany is trying very hard to be just. She didn’t grow up with a good moral example, but she strives to be better, while also trying to rule. And she is willing to change her ways and learn from her mistakes.

  • Practical aspects of ruling

Aside from trying to keep peace and bring justice, Dany also has to deal with the tedious aspects of ruling in Meereen. Dany is a very hands on ruler, and she doesn’t like to delegate too much:

“Your Grace takes too much on herself. You should allow your councillors to shoulder more of your burdens.”

“I have too many councillors and too few cushions.” Dany turned to Reznak. “How many more?” – Daenerys I ADWD

While maybe Dany does take too much on herself, this also means that she gets practice in the several aspects of the administration of a city. One of them is how to get the money that she needs:

Dany was shocked. “They want to be slaves?”

“The ones who come are well spoken and gently born, sweet queen. Such slaves are prized. In the Free Cities they will be tutors, scribes, bed slaves, even healers and priests. They will sleep in soft beds, eat rich foods, and dwell in manses. Here they have lost all, and live in fear and squalor.”

“I see.” Perhaps it was not so shocking, if these tales of Astapor were true. Dany thought a moment. “Any man who wishes to sell himself into slavery may do so. Or woman.” She raised a hand. “But they may not sell their children, nor a man his wife.”

“In Astapor the city took a tenth part of the price, each time a slave changed hands,” Missandei told her.

“We’ll do the same,” Dany decided. Wars were won with gold as much as swords. “A tenth part. In gold or silver coin, or ivory. Meereen has no need of saffron, cloves, or zorse hides.” – Daenerys VI ASOS

While Dany doesn’t like the idea of people selling themselves back into slavery, she thinks she must respect their choices (without allowing them to sell other people unwillingly). But, following Missandei’s suggestion, she takes a part of the money of those transactions. She turns something that she doesn’t like to do (allowing people to sell themselves), and tries to make use of it, and she knows that “wars are won with gold as much as swords”, meaning that Dany is not stupid and knows that armies are not the only source of power. (NOTE: I don’t think Dany should have allowed people to sell themselves back into slavery, because this means that she’s allowing part of the slave trade to continue, allowing that some people have the right to own others like objects. But Dany decided to take a moderate approach, and what I’m analysing in this section isn’t what she should have done overall, but how she dealt with the practical aspects of the administration of her city. As an administrative measure, I think that if Dany was going to let people sell themselves back into slavery, then she made a smart decision by taking a part of the money). Later, we see that Dany continues with this. As I already mentioned, she takes the wealth of the noble families that choose to leave Meereen. She also imposes a blood tax to pay the wages of the Brazen Beasts:

Reznak mo Reznak gasped. “Magnificence, where is the coin to come from to pay wages for so many men?”

“From the pyramids. Call it a blood tax. I will have a hundred pieces of gold from every pyramid for each freedman that the Harpy’s Sons have slain.” – Daenerys II ADWD

With this tax, Dany is trying to do two things at once: to get the money to pay for the soldiers that she needs, and to weaken the Meereenese noble families that conspire against her. It doesn’t work, because Dany is too mild with the slavers, and takes too little money from them. But this moment shows that Dany realizes that she can use taxes not only to fill the city’s coffers, but also to have political gains, like weakening her enemies. We also see other moments in which Dany uses taxes to get some benefit out of a situation that she doesn’t like:

“Your Magnificence,” whispered Reznak mo Reznak in her ear, “it is customary for the city to claim one-tenth of all the profits from the fighting pits, after expenses, as a tax. That coin might be put to many noble uses.”

“It might … though if we were to reopen the pits, we should take our tenth before expenses. I am only a young girl and know little of such matters, but I dwelt with Xaro Xhoan Daxos long enough to learn that much. Hizdahr, if you could marshal armies as you marshal arguments, you could conquer the world … but my answer is still no. For the sixth time.” – Daenerys I ADWD

Dany is also smart enough to know that corruption might be a problem, and she takes measures to prevent it:

“It shall be done as you command, glorious queen,” said Daario. “My Stormcrows will collect your tenth.”

If the Stormcrows saw to the collections at least half the gold would somehow go astray, Dany knew. But the Second Sons were just as bad, and the Unsullied were as unlettered as they were incorruptible. “Records must be kept,” she said. “Seek among the freedmen for men who can read, write, and do sums.” - Daenerys VI ASOS

There’s also another interesting moment in which Dany has to deal with the possibility that people will try to take advantage of her decrees:

“Three-and-twenty.” Dany sighed. “My dragons have developed a prodigious taste for mutton since we began to pay the shepherds for their kills. Have these claims been proven?”

“Some men have brought burnt bones.”

“Men make fires. Men cook mutton. Burnt bones prove nothing. Brown Ben says there are red wolves in the hills outside the city, and jackals and wild dogs. Must we pay good silver for every lamb that goes astray between Yunkai and the Skahazadhan?”

“No, Magnificence.” Reznak bowed. “Shall I send these rascals away, or will you want them scourged?”

Daenerys shifted on the bench. “No man should ever fear to come to me.” Some claims were false, she did not doubt, but more were genuine. Her dragons had grown too large to be content with rats and cats and dogs. The more they eat, the larger they will grow, Ser Barristan had warned her, and the larger they grow, the more they’ll eat. Drogon especially ranged far afield and could easily devour a sheep a day. “Pay them for the value of their animals,” she told Reznak, “but henceforth claimants must present themselves at the Temple of the Graces and swear a holy oath before the gods of Ghis.” – Daenerys I ADWD

Dany is smart enough to see that some people are deceiving her, but instead of doing what Reznak suggests, Dany knows that if she deals with people with brutality, they will fear ever coming to her again. Instead, she uses Meereen’s religious beliefs to dissuade people from making false claims. There are also several moments in which Dany states that she wants people to come to her with their problems, and that she doesn’t want them to be afraid to speak their minds or to criticize her:

“Your Grace,” said Whitebeard, “the Prince of Dragonstone was a most puissant warrior, but …”

“Go on,” she urged. “You may speak freely to me.” – Daenerys I ASOS

“I say no, Your Grace,” the old man answered at once.

“Why?” she asked. “Speak freely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

Whitebeard bowed his head. “Your Grace, I did not mean to give offense.”

“Only lies offend me, never honest counsel.” Dany patted Arstan’s spotted hand to reassure him. “I have a dragon’s temper, that’s all. You must not let it frighten you.” – Daenerys II ASOS

“Whitebeard,” she said, “I want your counsel, and you should never fear to speak your mind with me … when we are alone. But never question me in front of strangers. Is that understood?” – Daenerys III ASOS

“Then what do you advise, Ser Jorah?”

“You will not like it.”

“I would hear it all the same.” – Daenerys V ASOS

Dany also has to run investigations to find out who the Sons of the Harpy are, and has to find ways to protect her people and her soldiers from them. In the end, she doesn’t succeed (she only succeeds after she makes the peace deals), but Dany does take some important measures. She tries what she can to ensure the safety of her soldiers:

“… drawn in blood.” Daenerys knew the way of it by now. The Sons of the Harpy did their butchery by night, and over each kill they left their mark. “Grey Worm, why was this man alone? Had he no partner?” By her command, when the Unsullied walked the streets of Meereen by night they always walked in pairs. - Daenerys I ADWD

She also does what she can to conduct investigations:

“Send men to the Temple of the Graces and ask if any man has come to the Blue Graces with a sword wound. And spread the word that we will pay good gold for the short sword of Stalwart Shield. Inquire of the butchers and the herdsmen, and learn who has been gelding goats of late.” Perhaps some goatherd would confess. “Henceforth, no man of mine walks alone after dark.” - Daenerys I ADWD

Finally, Dany has to deal with a plague. And for her, it’s a lot of trial and error to try to find a solution to the pale mare situation:

Daenerys dare not open her gates to let them in. She had tried to do what she could for them. She had sent them healers, Blue Graces and spell-singers and barber-surgeons, but some of those had sickened as well, and none of their arts had slowed the galloping progression of the flux that had come on the pale mare. Separating the healthy from the sick had proved impractical as well. Her Stalwart Shields had tried, pulling husbands away from wives and children from their mothers, even as the Astapori wept and kicked and pelted them with stones. A few days later, the sick were dead and the healthy ones were sick. Dividing the one from the other had accomplished nothing. – Daenerys VI ADWD

Many shat where they slept now, too feeble to crawl to the ditches she’d commanded them to dig. Two women fought over a charred bone. Nearby a boy of ten stood eating a rat. He ate one-handed, the other clutching a sharpened stick lest anyone try to wrest away his prize. Unburied dead lay everywhere. Dany saw one man sprawled in the dirt under a black cloak, but as she rode past his cloak dissolved into a thousand flies. Skeletal women sat upon the ground clutching dying infants. Their eyes followed her. Those who had the strength called out. “Mother … please, Mother … bless you, Mother …” – Daenerys VI ADWD

“They are too feeble,” said Symon Stripeback.

Dany said, “More food might make them stronger.”

Symon shook his head. “Food should not be wasted on the dying, Your Worship. We do not have enough to feed the living.”

He was not wrong, she knew, but that did not make the words any easier to hear. “This is far enough,” the queen decided. “We’ll feed them here.” – Daenerys VI ADWD

Dany gazed across the camp, to the many-colored brick walls of Meereen. The air was thick with flies and cries. “The gods have sent this pestilence to humble me. So many dead … I will not have them eating corpses.” She beckoned Aggo closer. “Ride to the gates and bring me Grey Worm and fifty of his Unsullied.” – Daenerys VI ADWD

By the time Aggo returned with Grey Worm and fifty of the Unsullied loping behind his horse, Dany had shamed all of them into helping her. Symon Stripeback and his men were pulling the living from the dead and stacking up the corpses, while Jhogo and Rakharo and their Dothraki helped those who could still walk toward the shore to bathe and wash their clothes. Aggo stared at them as if they had all gone mad, but Grey Worm knelt beside the queen and said, “This one would be of help.”

Before midday a dozen fires were burning. Columns of greasy black smoke rose up to stain a merciless blue sky. Dany’s riding clothes were stained and sooty as she stepped back from the pyres. “Worship,” Grey Worm said, “this one and his brothers beg your leave to bathe in the salt sea when our work here is done, that we might be purified according to the laws of our great goddess.” – Daenerys VI ADWD

Though the queen had let the Astapori starve outside her walls to keep the bloody flux from spreading, it was spreading nonetheless. Many had been stricken: freedmen, sellswords, Brazen Beasts, even Dothraki, though as yet none of the Unsullied had been touched. She prayed the worst was past. – Daenerys VII ADWD

I think the quotes above are very interesting because we can see Dany gaining experience as she tries to control the situation. She tries sending healers, but they get sick. She tries separating sick and healthy, but soon sees that people don’t want to be separated from their loved ones. She tries giving them more food. She digs ditches, burn corpses and helps to clean people. Those things show that Dany has some idea that she needs to be careful to not spread the disease (she closes the gates), and at the same time, she also understands that hygiene is important. I think that the observation about how the Unsullied were not touched by the plague is something that, in the future, will be useful for Dany, something that she will remember. In conclusion, I think these moments show just how much Dany is trying to learn from the situation, how she seems to be taking note of what works and what doesn’t. I think Dany will come out of this much more prepared to deal with similar situations when necessary, and I think this is important to her growth as a ruler as well.

In my opinion, Dany has shown herself to be very smart and capable of dealing with the practical aspects of the administration of a city.

  • Dany’s equalitarian practices

One thing that distinguishes Dany as a ruler is how she gives power and voice to the smallfolk. She listens to them at court and council, and gives them the same respect:

Reznak would have summoned another tokar next, but Dany insisted that he call upon a freedman. Thereafter she alternated between the former masters and the former slaves. – Daenerys I ADWD

Rylona Rhee had played the harp as sweetly as the Maiden. When she had been a slave in Yunkai, she had played for every highborn family in the city. In Meereen she had become a leader amongst the Yunkish freedmen, their voice in Dany's councils. – Daenerys II ADWD

Late that afternoon Admiral Groleo and Ser Barristan returned from their inspection of the galleys. Dany assembled her council to hear them. Grey Worm was there for the Unsullied, Skahaz mo Kandaq for the Brazen Beasts. In the absence of her bloodriders, a wizened jaqqa rhan called Rommo, squint-eyed and bowlegged, came to speak for her Dothraki. Her freedmen were represented by the captains of the three companies she had formed—Mollono Yos Dob of the Stalwart Shields, Symon Stripeback of the Free Brothers, Marselen of the Mother’s Men. Reznak mo Reznak hovered at the queen’s elbow, and Strong Belwas stood behind her with his huge arms crossed. – Daenerys III ADWD

  • Some mistakes worth addressing

One mistake that Dany makes is that she takes hostages, but fails to kill them when the Sons of the Harpy attack. If she wasn’t going to kill her hostages, she shouldn’t have taken hostages in the first place. But it’s important to remember that Dany understands her failure in this situation:

Dany pushed her food about her plate. She dare not glance over to where Grazhar and Qezza stood, for fear that she might cry. The Shavepate has a harder heart than mine. They had fought about the hostages half a dozen times. “The Sons of the Harpy are laughing in their pyramids,” Skahaz said, just this morning. “What good are hostages if you will not take their heads?” In his eyes, she was only a weak woman. Hazzea was enough. What good is peace if it must be purchased with the blood of little children? “These murders are not their doing,” Dany told the Green Grace, feebly. “I am no butcher queen.” - Daenerys IV ADWD

It’s not like Dany doesn’t know she made a mistake. She knows the Shavepate sees her as weak, and she knows her enemies must think this as well. So I believe that in the future, Dany won’t take hostages unless she intends to kill them.

There are also moments in which Dany is too open:

“On what terms?” Beware the perfumed seneschal, Quaithe had said. The masked woman had foretold the coming of the pale mare, was she right about the noble Reznak too? “I may be a young girl innocent of war, but I am not a lamb to walk bleating into the harpy’s den. I still have my Unsullied. I have the Stormcrows and the Second Sons. I have three companies of freedmen.”

“Them, and dragons,” said Brown Ben Plumm, with a grin.

“In the pit, in chains,” wailed Reznak mo Reznak. “What good are dragons that cannot be controlled? Even the Unsullied grow fearful when they must open the doors to feed them.”

“What, o’ the queen’s little pets?” Brown Ben’s eyes crinkled in amusement. The grizzled captain of the Second Sons was a creature of the free companies, a mongrel with the blood of a dozen different peoples flowing through his veins, but he had always been fond of the dragons, and them of him.

“Pets?” screeched Reznak. “Monsters, rather. Monsters that feed on children. We cannot—”

“Silence,” said Daenerys. “We will not speak of that.”

Reznak shrank away from her, flinching from the fury in her tone. “Forgive me, Magnificence, I did not …”

[…]

Dany sighed. “I am sorry, Ben. I dare not loose the dragons.” She could see that was not the answer that he wanted. - Daenerys V ADWD

In this scene, we can see that Dany tries to control the information, and she tries to silence Reznak when he starts to speak too much. But in the end, she ends up telling Ben that she will not use the dragons, which ends up leading to him betraying her. But I think this can be seen as a slip, not a flaw in Dany as a ruler, because we see in several other moments that Dany is not a gullible person. She distrusts Xaro and Pyat Pree in Qarth, and in Meereen, she refuses to tell Xaro her secrets:

“Is that meant to frighten me? I lived in fear for fourteen years, my lord. I woke afraid each morning and went to sleep afraid each night … but my fears were burned away the day I came forth from the fire. Only one thing frightens me now.”

“And what is it that you fear, sweet queen?”

“I am only a foolish young girl.” Dany rose on her toes and kissed his cheek. “But not so foolish as to tell you that. My men shall look at these ships. Then you shall have my answer.” - Daenerys III ADWD

She also tells Hazzea’s father that he shouldn’t tell anyone about what happened. Even in the scene in which she tells Ben that she can’t use her dragons, she does try to be cautious about the information she discloses, and she can recognize her mistake with Ben Brown Plumm:

“Never that,” said Brown Ben, “but it’s not all about the coin, Your High-and-Mightiness. […] Silver’s sweet and gold’s our mother, but once you’re dead they’re worth less than that last shit you take as you lie dying. I told you once, there are old sellswords and there are bold sellswords, but there are no old bold sellswords. My boys didn’t care to die, that’s all, and when I told them that you couldn’t unleash them dragons against the Yunkishmen, well …”

You saw me as defeated, Dany thought, and who am I to say that you were wrong? - Daenerys VIII ADWD

So I would say this was mostly a slip. Dany is not an stupid and naive person, and she can see what her mistakes were.

Another thing that Dany fails to do is that, as Tyrion notes, is that she doesn’t poison the well outside Meereen, which would have helped her to defeat the siege of the Yunkai’i. We are never told the reasons for it in Dany’s POV, but if I could guess, I imagine it’s for the same reason that Dany has been so insistent on peace: she knows that if she poisons the wells, she would be condemning the Astapori refugees to death. We still don’t know what Dany will do next in her story, but I guess it’s understandable why Dany doesn’t do this, because she’s trying to do the right thing.

Finally, we also have this moment, in which Dany and Barristan are talking about the Brazen Beasts:

“A mask can hide many things, Your Grace. Is the man behind the owl mask the same owl who guarded you yesterday and the day before? How can we know?”

“How should Meereen ever come to trust the Brazen Beasts if I do not? There are good brave men beneath those masks. I put my life into their hands.” Dany smiled for him. “You fret too much, ser. I will have you beside me, what other protection do I need?” – Daenerys IX ADWD

There are pros and cons in each approach. The reason for the mask of the Brazen Beasts is for them to not be recognized, so they won’t be targeted and attacked by the Sons of the Harpy. And from the perspective of someone that is seeking peace, Dany is right in saying that she can´t ask Meereen to trust the Brazen Beasts if she doesn´t. It´s a question of appearances: she needs to show confidence if she wants her people to feel safe and trust the Brazen Beasts. On the other hand, Barristan is right in saying that masks can make it easier for her enemies to hide (though Dany is not completely unprotected. She still keeps people she trusts by her side, like Barristan and Belwas, so it’s not like Dany is neglectful of her own safety). Besides, Dany has let Hizdahr appoint a cousin to the command of the Brazen Beasts, which is bad for her, because this could make her lose control of one of her more important military forces. So there are good points to be made in favor of Dany’s decisions here, but also good points against her decisions.

I think these mistakes show that Dany isn’t perfect, but in no way they mean that Dany is a bad ruler. They mean that Dany is a human being, so sometimes she slips, while also trying to do what’s right. And Dany does understand some of her mistakes. She’s mindful of them, which is a positive thing.

IS DAENERYS A GOOD RULER? WHAT DID SHE LEARN?

Now let’s look at Dany’s whole journey. In AGOT, Dany learns the importance of culture and traditions, she learns how to be strong and assertive, and with Jorah Mormont, she asks for information about Westeros and the Dothraki that her brother never bothers to ask.

In ACOK, Dany leads her people out of the Red Waste by giving an example of strength, determination, care for her people, respect for their culture, pragmatism and by making the sensible decision to send her bloodriders to find a way out of the desert so they don’t have to walk blindly through the desert. In Qarth, she’s suspicious and cautious but not paranoid, she escapes deceptions and temptations, and finds a new resolve.

In ASOS, Dany makes brilliant battle plans, but also big mistakes. But she learns from her mistakes: she understands her failure in leaving Astapor behind without an army to protect it, and she understands her failure in leaving the masters of Yunkai in power.

In ADWD, Dany does everything possible to rebuild the economy (she plants crops, negotiates for trade, and make compromises to lift the siege against Meereen), and to keep the people of Meereen free. She deals well with taxes, and does everything she can to stop the plague. She trains new soldier companies to protect her city, and later tries to make the sellswords change sides, because she know that she must be prepared if the peace breaks. She makes compromises to bring peace, and acts accordingly to make the peace deals work. In my opinion, all of this shows that Dany was a very good ruler in Meereen. She took a very sensible course of action, probably the best she could have done in the circumstances, because she didn’t have enough military power to defeat the slavers. Her willingness to make compromises shows that she is the kind of ruler who seeks peaceful solutions. But in the end, Dany comes to reflect on the pros and cons of peace, and decides that the peace wasn’t worth it, because it was an unjust peace. This is important because Dany needs to know when to look for peaceful solutions, and when war is necessary. Dany will certainly come out of this as a more decisive and mature ruler.

Besides, her actions as a queen that cares about her people are bearing fruits. Her people still love her and support her even in the direst times:

Dany saw one man sprawled in the dirt under a black cloak, but as she rode past his cloak dissolved into a thousand flies. Skeletal women sat upon the ground clutching dying infants. Their eyes followed her. Those who had the strength called out. “Mother … please, Mother … bless you, Mother …"  – Daenerys VI ADWD

Later, when Dany is gone from the city, her people are still loyal to her:

When His Grace had tried to put them under the command of a cousin, as he had the Brazen Beasts, Grey Worm had informed the king that they were free men who took commands only from their mother. – The Queensguard ADWD

"Is it true?” a freedwoman shouted. “Is our mother dead?”

“No, no, no,” Reznak screeched. “Queen Daenerys will return to Meereen in her own time in all her might and majesty. Until such time, His Worship King Hizdahr shall—”

“He is no king of mine,” a freedman yelled. – The Discarded Knight ADWD

Their loyalty to Dany is what keeps everyone together:

A young girl she might be, but Daenerys Targaryen was the only thing that held them all together. – The Queen’s Hand ADWD

And people continue fighting for Dany. Barristan deposes Hizdahr for the suspicion that he was the one that tried to poison her. When Yunkai attacks in the TWOW chapters that were released, the Mother’s Men, Free Brothers, Stalwart Shields, the pit fighters and the Brazen Beasts are all there willing to fight, even though Yunkai has the numerical advantage. And it’s not only loyalty for Dany, but also the hope that she gave them, that they can fight for their own freedom. The revolution that Dany started is not just in her hands anymore, it’s being carried by everyone else. That’s her legacy. And it’s a great thing that Daenerys was able to accomplish that.

Dany is politically savvy. She is observant, capable of adapting to other cultures and to different situations, speaks several languages, listens to her people regardless of birth or social status, cares for women, sees her position of queen as a duty to her people, is self critical, conciliatory, merciful (even if she does get angry and make mistakes sometimes), courteous, understands the importance of keeping up appearances and manipulating people’s perceptions of her and of the different situations, is pragmatic, knows how to assess the strength of each man under her command and use them accordingly, always tries to learn more and seeks for information, listens to counsel, is not gullible but is not paranoid either, respects people’s humanity and tries to make social chances that benefit the oppressed. She is good at understanding people’s motivations (like Hizdahr’s true intentions in reopening the fighting pits), she understands supply and demand, understands symbols of power (like the tokar), understands that she can’t answer people with brutality or else her people will be afraid to come to her, and understands that she needs to be seen caring about her people. She has gained experience in managing the economy, avoiding corruption, commanding armies, diplomacy and compromises. And she has gained a more mature understanding of peace and war.

Dany still has things to learn, of course. She has now decided on a fire and blood path. I do believe this is necessary to end slavery and that making peace with the slavers was the wrong choice. But it’s also very likely that Dany will make mistakes, and at some points, she might go too far with fire and blood.  She has an even bigger internal conflict coming her way in The Winds of Winter: how far is Dany willing to go? What kind of violence is justified? But this is important for Dany to learn. She won’t become the perfect ruler in a single day. And Dany has an even bigger responsibility, because she owns the only dragons in the entire world, and has to learn how to wield a huge power responsibly.

But regardless of what happens in future books, I do think that, given all I discussed here, Dany is a great leader and a great ruler.
trail.content:
For the longest time, I wanted to write about Dany as a leader and a ruler. Most of the time, the metas I see from Dany haters just talk about what an awful ruler Dany is, and amongst Daenerys fans, this is usually not discussed a lot, mostly because I think Dany fans spend a lot of time defending Dany from the accusations that she is evil or mad, so other subjects are neglected. Before I start, I just want to make it clear that I am not any expert on medieval politics or war strategy, so this will be mostly my understanding of the story. And of course, I can’t forget to mention that many of the ideas of the Meereenese Blot are here as well, but this is going to be my interpretation.

In this analysis, I will show why I think Daenerys is an intelligent and capable leader and ruler. I want to look at everything we know about Dany in all of the books: her childhood and education, her political beliefs, her actions and the economic and political situation she’s in. I’ll try to focus on what Dany has learned in each book, and how it helped her become a better leader.

Some of the things I’ll write here are similar to metas that I’ve written before. But I want this one to be as complete as possible, and to analyze every facet of Dany’s storyline as a ruler that I can think of. I will bring book quotes to back up what I say, so this will be very long (It’s around 20k words, so I hope at least someone will be interested in reading it, because I spent months scrutinizing all of the books to write this).

In this essay, I will talk about the following topics:

Dany’s childhood and education

Dany’s intelligence, wisdom and introspectiveness

Dany’s changing political views

Dany journey as a leader in A Game of Thrones

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Clash of Kings

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Storm of Swords

Dany’s journey as a leader in A Dance with Dragons:

  • Economy
  • The war against Yunkai and the question of peace and war
  • The question of taking the wealth of the slave masters
  • Conflicting interests within the city
  • Morality
  • Practical aspects or ruling
  • Dany’s equalitarian practices
  • Some mistakes worth addressing

Is Daenerys a good ruler? What did she learn?

DANY’S CHILDHOOD AND EDUCATION

Dany spent her childhood poor, homeless, and had to go from place to place, never stopping for too long. She didn’t have money or stability to have a formal education:

After Ser Willem had died, the servants had stolen what little money they had left, and soon after they had been put out of the big house. Dany had cried when the red door closed behind them forever.

They had wandered since then, from Braavos to Myr, from Myr to Tyrosh, and on to Qohor and Volantis and Lys, never staying long in any one place. Her brother would not allow it. The Usurper’s hired knives were close behind them, he insisted, though Dany had never seen one.

At first the magisters and archons and merchant princes were pleased to welcome the last Targaryens to their homes and tables, but as the years passed and the Usurper continued to sit upon the Iron Throne, doors closed and their lives grew meaner. Years past they had been forced to sell their last few treasures, and now even the coin they had gotten from Mother’s crown had gone. In the alleys and wine sinks of Pentos, they called her brother “the beggar king.” Dany did not want to know what they called her. – Daenerys I AGOT

Dany later confirms that she indeed never had any formal education:

“Tell me of this other Daenerys. I know less than I should of the history of my father’s kingdom. I never had a maester growing up.” Only a brother. – Daenerys VIII ADWD

But we also have this quote:

“A queen must listen to all,” […] She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

Dany spent her childhood poor, homeless, without receiving a formal education. Most of what Dany knows comes from Viserys, from her own experience, and from a few books she has read. Given that Dany and Viserys were poor, I imagine that the only times that Dany had access to books were when they were guests at some archon’s or prince’s home, and this was only in the beginning, before the doors started closing on them. I think this is the first thing we need to know if we want to understand Dany’s mistakes and beliefs, and not crucify her for them. Daenerys is not supposed to start the story as a great leader who makes no mistakes. Her story, from the very beginning, is all about learning.

DANY’S INTELLIGENCE, WISDOM AND INTROSPECTIVENESS

Despite lacking education and experience, Dany shows herself to be very intelligent and wise.

Dany is observant, always aware of her situation, surroundings and of the people around her:

Magister Illyrio was a dealer in spices, gemstones, dragonbone, and other, less savory things. He had friends in all of the Nine Free Cities, it was said, and even beyond, in Vaes Dothrak and the fabled lands beside the Jade Sea. It was also said that he’d never had a friend he wouldn’t cheerfully sell for the right price. Dany listened to the talk in the streets, and she heard these things, but she knew better than to question her brother when he wove his webs of dream. – Daenerys I AGOT

The cobbler thanked her for that, and the old brickmaker kissed her foot, but the weaver looked at her with eyes as hard as slate. She knows I lie, the queen thought. - Daenerys V ADWD

She is not gullible:

“Why does he give us so much?” she asked. “What does he want from us?” For nigh on half a year, they had lived in the magister’s house, eating his food, pampered by his servants. Dany was thirteen, old enough to know that such gifts seldom come without their price, here in the free city of Pentos. – Daenerys I AGOT

“They are your people, and they love you well,” Magister Illyrio said amiably. “In holdfasts all across the realm, men lift secret toasts to your health while women sew dragon banners and hide them against the day of your return from across the water.” He gave a massive shrug. “Or so my agents tell me.”

Dany had no agents, no way of knowing what anyone was doing or thinking across the narrow sea, but she mistrusted Illyrio’s sweet words as she mistrusted everything about Illyrio. – Daenerys I AGOT

Dany took the warlock’s words well salted, but the magnificence of the great city was not to be denied. – Daenerys II ACOK

“I do not understand her.” Pyat and Xaro had showered Dany with promises from the moment they first glimpsed her dragons, declaring themselves her loyal servants in all things, but from Quaithe she had gotten only the rare cryptic word. And it disturbed her that she had never seen the woman’s face. Remember Mirri Maz Duur, she told herself. Remember treachery. She turned to her bloodriders. “We will keep our own watch so long as we are here. See that no one enters this wing of the palace without my leave, and take care that the dragons are always well guarded.” – Daenerys II ACOK

Thirteen. To be sure. Xaro was one of the Thirteen. No doubt he had convinced each of his fellow members to give up one ship. She knew the merchant prince too well to think that he would sacrifice thirteen of his own ships. “I must consider this. May I inspect these ships?”

“You have grown suspicious, Daenerys.”

Always. “I have grown wise, Xaro.” - Daenerys III ADWD

But at the same time, Dany is not paranoid, and she knows that she needs to take risks to get what she wants or needs:

“It seems to me that a queen who trusts no one is as foolish as a queen who trusts everyone. Every man I take into my service is a risk, I understand that, but how am I to win the Seven Kingdoms without such risks? Am I to conquer Westeros with one exile knight and three Dothraki bloodriders?” – Daenerys I ASOS

“I am glad you came to me. It is good to see your face again, my friend.” I will not trust you, but I need you. I need your Thirteen, I need your ships, I need your trade. - Daenerys III ADWD

We continue to see this attitude in all of the books, with good, bad and uncertain results: Dany trusts Barristan, which was a good thing. Despite being warned by Quaithe’s prophecies and the prophecies of the House of the Undying, Dany is not paranoid about them. She is aware of the danger from Reznak (who she thinks is the perfumed seneschal) and Quentyn (the Sun’s son), the danger from sellswords and people in her court, but she tries to make use of everyone even though she doesn’t fully trust them, trying not to be gullible but without being paranoid.

Dany is very adaptable and respects different cultures, which enables her to survive different situations, while her brother fails:

Viserys came upon her as sudden as a summer storm, his horse rearing beneath him as he reined up too hard. “You dare!” he screamed at her. “You give commands to me? To me?” He vaulted off the horse, stumbling as he landed. His face was flushed as he struggled back to his feet. He grabbed her, shook her. “Have you forgotten who you are? Look at you. Look at you!”

Dany did not need to look. She was barefoot, with oiled hair, wearing Dothraki riding leathers and a painted vest given her as a bride gift. She looked as though she belonged here. Viserys was soiled and stained in city silks and ringmail. – Daenerys III AGOT

She’s also very introspective, capable of reflecting on her experiences and mistakes, and always tries to learn and improve. One of the things she tries to improve is her magical knowledge:

“I thank you, Mirri Maz Duur,” she said, “for the lessons you have taught me.”

“You will not hear me scream,” Mirri responded as the oil dripped from her hair and soaked her clothing.

“I will,” Dany said, “but it is not your screams I want, only your life. I remember what you told me. Only death can pay for life.” – Daenerys X AGOT

And when Dany’s bloodriders and Ser Jorah tell Dany to not enter the House of The Undying, Dany tells them that the reason she wants to go is to obtain more knowledge:

Ser Jorah Mormont gave the merchant prince a sour look. “Your Grace, remember Mirri Maz Duur.”

“I do,” Dany said, suddenly decided. “I remember that she had knowledge. And she was only a maegi.” – Daenerys IV ACOK

She tries to improve her military knowledge:

Dany reined in her mare and looked across the fields, to where the Yunkish host lay athwart her path. Whitebeard had been teaching her how best to count the numbers of a foe. “Five thousand,” she said after a moment. – Daenerys IV ASOS

She loves books, and tries to learn from them:

Ser Jorah Mormont apologized for his gift. “It is a small thing, my princess, but all a poor exile could afford,” he said as he laid a small stack of old books before her. They were histories and songs of the Seven Kingdoms, she saw, written in the Common Tongue. She thanked him with all her heart. – Daenerys II AGOT

“A queen must listen to all,”[…] She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

“I’m cold,” Dany lied. “Bring me the book I was reading last night.” She wanted to lose herself in the words, in other times and other places. The fat leather-bound volume was full of songs and stories from the Seven Kingdoms. Children’s stories, if truth be told; too simple and fanciful to be true history. All the heroes were tall and handsome, and you could tell the traitors by their shifty eyes. Yet she loved them all the same. Last night she had been reading of the three princesses in the red tower, locked away by the king for the crime of being beautiful. – Daenerys VI ASOS

Dragons are fire made flesh. She had read that in one of the books Ser Jorah had given her as a wedding gift. – Daenerys I ADWD

“You … you mean to ride them?”

“One of them. All I know of dragons is what my brother told me when I was a girl, and some I read in books, but it is said that even Aegon the Conqueror never dared mount Vhagar or Meraxes, nor did his sisters ride Balerion the Black Dread. Dragons live longer than men, some for hundreds of years, so Balerion had other riders after Aegon died … but no rider ever flew two dragons.” – Daenerys VIII ADWD

She always tries to listen to people, and use their advice when she lacks the necessary knowledge:

“A queen must listen to all,” she reminded him. “The highborn and the low, the strong and the weak, the noble and the venal. One voice may speak you false, but in many there is always truth to be found.” She had read that in a book. – Daenerys I ASOS

The old man had not wanted to sail to Astapor; nor did he favor buying this slave army. A queen should hear all sides before reaching a decision. That was why Dany had brought him with her to the Plaza of Pride, not to keep her safe. – Daenerys II ASOS

“Aggo, Jhoqo, and Rakharo still serve me.” He is playing games with me. Dany could play as well. “I am only a young girl and know little of such things, but older, wiser men tell me that to hold Meereen I must control its hinterlands, all the land west of Lhazar as far south as the Yunkish hills.” – Daenerys III ADWD

Dany had no answer for that. If this is truly what my people wish, do I have the right to deny it to them? It was their city before it was mine, and it is their own lives they wish to squander. “I will consider all you’ve said. Thank you for your counsel.” She rose. “We will resume on the morrow.” – Daenerys II ADWD

Dany is also very introspective and self critical, always reflecting on her experiences and mistakes, and deciding that she needs to learn how to rule:

That morning she summoned her captains and commanders to the garden, rather than descending to the audience chamber. “Aegon the Conqueror brought fire and blood to Westeros, but afterward he gave them peace, prosperity, and justice. But all I have brought to Slaver’s Bay is death and ruin. I have been more khal than queen, smashing and plundering, then moving on.”

[…]

“You have brought freedom as well,” Missandei pointed out.

“Freedom to starve?” asked Dany sharply. “Freedom to die? Am I a dragon, or a harpy?” Am I mad? Do I have the taint?

“A dragon,” Ser Barristan said with certainty. “Meereen is not Westeros, Your Grace.”

“But how can I rule seven kingdoms if I cannot rule a single city?” He had no answer to that. Dany turned away from them, to gaze out over the city once again. “My children need time to heal and learn. My dragons need time to grow and test their wings. And I need the same. I will not let this city go the way of Astapor. I will not let the harpy of Yunkai chain up those I’ve freed all over again.” She turned back to look at their faces. “I will not march.”

“What will you do then, Khaleesi?” asked Rakharo.

“Stay,” she said. “Rule. And be a queen.” – Daenerys VI ASOS

“Your Grace could not have known—”

“I am the queen. It was my place to know.” – Daenerys V ADWD

She also knows that she needs to learn more about the kingdom that she intends to rule:

“Tell me of this other Daenerys. I know less than I should of the history of my father’s kingdom. I never had a maester growing up.” Only a brother. – Daenerys VIII ADWD

This gift for self-reflection is something we see constantly in ADWD as well, while Dany ponders what’s the best course of action in Meereen.

Dany is pragmatic. In Vaes Tolorro, her people don’t want to enter the city out of fear, but Dany insists:

“I fear no ghosts. Dragons are more powerful than ghosts.” And figs are more important. – Daenerys I ACOK

We can also see her pragmatism in relation to war and conquest:

The thought of home disquieted her. If her sun-and-stars had lived, he would have led his khalasar across the poison water and swept away her enemies, but his strength had left the world. Her bloodriders remained, sworn to her for life and skilled in slaughter, but only in the ways of the horselords. The Dothraki sacked cities and plundered kingdoms, they did not rule them. Dany had no wish to reduce King’s Landing to a blackened ruin full of unquiet ghosts. She had supped enough on tears. I want to make my kingdom beautiful, to fill it with fat men and pretty maids and laughing children. I want my people to smile when they see me ride by, the way Viserys said they smiled for my father.

But before she could do that she must conquer. – Daenerys II ACOK

“My queen,” said Arstan, “there have been no slaves in the Seven Kingdoms for thousands of years. The old gods and the new alike hold slavery to be an abomination. Evil. If you should land in Westeros at the head of a slave army, many good men will oppose you for no other reason than that. You will do great harm to your cause, and to the honor of your House.”

“Yet I must have some army,” Dany said. “The boy Joffrey will not give me the Iron Throne for asking politely.” – Daenerys II ASOS

Dany is politically intelligent. She very easily sees the political consequences of Robert’s death (she doesn’t have the full picture, but she very quickly understands the flaws in her reasoning when Jorah points it out):

“Before, the Seven Kingdoms were like my Drogo's khalasar, a hundred thousand made as one by his strength. Now they fly to pieces, even as the khalasar did after my khal lay dead.” – Daenerys II ACOK

She can see Hizdahr’s true intention behind the reopening of the fighting pits, and she’s capable of making an analysis of the political and economic situation she’s in:

I need this man, Dany reminded herself. Hizdahr was a wealthy merchant with many friends in Meereen, and more across the seas. He had visited Volantis, Lys, and Qarth, had kin in Tolos and Elyria, and was even said to wield some influence in New Ghis, where the Yunkai'i were trying to stir up enmity against Dany and her rule.

And he was rich. Famously and fabulously rich …

And like to grow richer, if I grant his petition. When Dany had closed the city's fighting pits, the value of pit shares had plummeted. Hizdahr zo Loraq had grabbed them up with both hands, and now owned most of the fighting pits in Meereen. – Daenerys I ADWD

A brothel. Half of her freedmen were from Yunkai, where the Wise Masters had been famed for training bedslaves. The way of the seven sighs. Brothels had sprouted up like mushrooms all over Meereen. It is all they know. They need to survive. Food was more costly every day, whilst the price of flesh grew cheaper. In the poorer districts between the stepped pyramids of Meereen’s slaver nobility, there were brothels catering to every conceivable erotic taste, she knew. - Daenerys I ADWD

She understands supply and demand:

“I am trying to set a price on one of the three living dragons in the world.“ Dany smiled at him sweetly. "It seems to me that one-third of all the ships in the world would be fair.” – Daenerys V ACOK

She understands the need to compromise, and that it’s not enough to conquer a city, she also needs to win over the people:

To rule Meereen I must win the Meereenese, however much I may despise them. - Daenerys I ADWD

She understands that she needs to be careful about keeping up appearances and manipulating how other people perceive her:

That was Drogon's victory, not mine, Dany wanted to say, but she held her tongue. The Dothraki would esteem her all the more for a few bells in her hair. – Daenerys V ACOK

“Whitebeard,” she said, “I want your counsel, and you should never fear to speak your mind with me … when we are alone. But never question me in front of strangers. Is that understood?” – Daenerys III ASOS

The rest of her people followed: Groleo and the other captains and their crews, and the eighty-three Dothraki who remained to her of the hundred thousand who had once ridden in Drogo’s khalasar. She put the oldest and weakest on the inside of the column, with the nursing women and those with child, and the little girls, and the boys too young to braid their hair. The rest—her warriors, such as they were—rode outside and moved their dismal herd along, the hundred-odd gaunt horses that had survived both red waste and black salt sea. – Daenerys III ASOS

She thinks a ruler must keep a cool head and be merciful:

If I wed Hizdahr, will that turn Skahaz against me? She trusted Skahaz more than she trusted Hizdahr, but the Shavepate would be a disaster as a king. He was too quick to anger, too slow to forgive. - Daenerys IV ADWD

She understands that she needs to be seen caring for her people:

“Go if you wish, ser. I will not detain you. I will not detain any of you.” Dany vaulted down from the horse. “I cannot heal them, but I can show them that their Mother cares.” - Daenerys VI ADWD

But even though she has to keep up appearances, she tries to be just:

Her name had been Hazzea. She was four years old. Unless her father lied. He might have lied. No one had seen the dragon but him. His proof was burned bones, but burned bones proved nothing. He might have killed the little girl himself, and burned her afterward. He would not have been the first father to dispose of an unwanted girl child, the Shavepate claimed. The Sons of the Harpy might have done it, and made it look like dragon’s work to make the city hate me. Dany wanted to believe that … but if that was so, why had Hazzea’s father waited until the audience hall was almost empty to come forward? If his purpose had been to inflame the Meereenese against her, he would have told his tale when the hall was full of ears to hear.

The Shavepate had urged her to put the man to death. “At least rip out his tongue. This man’s lie could destroy us all, Magnificence.” Instead Dany chose to pay the blood price. No one could tell her the worth of a daughter, so she set it at one hundred times the worth of a lamb. “I would give Hazzea back to you if I could,” she told the father, “but some things are beyond the power of even a queen. Her bones shall be laid to rest in the Temple of the Graces, and a hundred candles shall burn day and night in her memory. Come back to me each year upon her nameday, and your other children shall not want … but this tale must never pass your lips again.” – Daenerys II ADWD

This quote shows that Dany is smart and capable of analysing the situation to conclude that Hazzea’s father was telling the truth. She knows that she has to keep the tale from spreading, but she also understands that it’s important to be fair to her people, so she chooses to be kind and be just to Hazzea’s father.

With all of this being said, I think Dany has many qualities of a great ruler.

DANY’S CHANGING POLITICAL VIEWS

Thanks to Dany’s ability for self-reflection, Dany changes her political views throughout the story due to her experiences. She starts the story as a very naïve girl who doesn’t truly understands the costs of war and conquest, asking her husband to invade the Seven Kingdoms without really realizing what the consequences would be. First, she tries to convince Drogo several times, unsuccessfully. Then, the wineseller tries to poison her and Drogo decides to cross the narrow sea. He attacks the Lhazareen to pay for the ships, and Dany finally sees the consequences of her actions:

Slaves, Dany thought. Khal Drogo would drive them downriver to one of the towns on Slaver’s Bay. She wanted to cry, but she told herself that she must be strong. This is war, this is what it looks like, this is the price of the Iron Throne. – Daenerys VII AGOT

But Dany is unable to ignore the horror, and two paragraphs later, she tries to put a stop at least to the rapes, with the little power she has. She defies Dothraki culture and Drogo’s men, putting herself at risk:

Behind them, the girl being raped made a heartrending sound, a long sobbing wail that went on and on and on. Dany’s hand clenched hard around the reins, and she turned the silver’s head. “Make them stop,” she commanded Ser Jorah. – Daenerys VII AGOT

Later, Dany reflects on what she thinks is acceptable in war and conquest, trying to be pragmatic but without unnecessary bloodshed:

Blood and fire, thought Dany. The words of House Targaryen. She had known them all her life. “The blood of my enemies I will shed gladly. The blood of innocents is another matter. Eight thousand Unsullied they would offer me. Eight thousand dead babes. Eight thousand strangled dogs.” – Daenerys II ASOS

“Your Grace,” she corrected. “Prince Rhaegar led free men into battle, not slaves. Whitebeard said he dubbed his squires himself, and made many other knights as well.”

“There was no higher honor than to receive your knighthood from the Prince of Dragonstone.”

“Tell me, then—when he touched a man on the shoulder with his sword, what did he say? ‘Go forth and kill the weak’? Or 'Go forth and defend them’? At the Trident, those brave men Viserys spoke of who died beneath our dragon banners—did they give their lives because they believed in Rhaegar’s cause, or because they had been bought and paid for?” Dany turned to Mormont, crossed her arms, and waited for an answer. – Daenerys II ASOS

Another thing that changes are her views on slavery. Dany starts as someone who lives in a slave society and has no strong feelings against slavery. While she was living with Illyrio, she had slaves serving her, and with the Dothraki, she had slave servants as well. But as soon as Drogo dies, Dany frees her slaves. Even then, while Dany no longer has slaves herself, she has no strong feelings about the slaves in Qarth, and even considers buying a slave army. But when Dany sees the horrors in Astapor and understands what slavery truly means, she turns away from it:

Xaro caught it in the air and took a bite. “Whence came this madness? Should I count myself fortunate that you did not free my own slaves when you were my guest in Qarth?”

I was a beggar queen and you were Xaro of the Thirteen, Dany thought, and all you wanted were my dragons. “Your slaves seemed well treated and content. It was not till Astapor that my eyes were opened. Do you know how Unsullied are made and trained?” – Daenerys III ADWD

And despite being raised by Viserys, Dany was able to think on her on view on what a king should be, and what are her duties as a monarch:

“I was alone for a long time, Jorah. All alone but for my brother. I was such a small scared thing. Viserys should have protected me, but instead he hurt me and scared me worse. He shouldn’t have done that. He wasn’t just my brother, he was my king. Why do the gods make kings and queens, if not to protect the ones who can’t protect themselves?”

“Some kings make themselves. Robert did.”

“He was no true king,” Dany said scornfully. “He did no justice. Justice … that’s what kings are for.” – Daenerys III ASOS

A queen belongs not to herself but to her people. – Daenerys V ADWD

Daenerys was only able to change her views and become a more conscious ruler because of her self-reflection and empathy, and this is one of the things that sets her apart as a leader. With all that being said, let’s see Dany’s journey in each of the books.

FINDING HER WAY IN THE WORLD

The first two books are, in my opinion, about Daenerys finding out what she wants and what to do. It’s the beginning of her journey as a leader, and she’s going on instinct, trying to find out what to do.

A GAME OF THRONES

People usually look at this book as the story of a scared little girl overcoming abuse and becoming stronger. This is all true, but this is also the book where Dany starts to develop her leadership skills. In this book, Dany learns how to be more assertive and how to deal with this new authority that is given to her:

“Wait here,” Dany told Ser Jorah. “Tell them all to stay. Tell them I command it.”

The knight smiled. Ser Jorah was not a handsome man. He had a neck and shoulders like a bull, and coarse black hair covered his arms and chest so thickly that there was none left for his head. Yet his smiles gave Dany comfort. “You are learning to talk like a queen, Daenerys.”

“Not a queen,” said Dany. “A khaleesi.” She wheeled her horse about and galloped down the ridge alone. – Daenerys III AGOT

Unlike Viserys, Dany learns about Dothraki culture and adapts to it. This allows her to gain more respect than her brother:

“Take his horse,” Dany commanded Ser Jorah. Viserys gaped at her. He could not believe what he was hearing; nor could Dany quite believe what she was saying. Yet the words came. “Let my brother walk behind us back to the khalasar.” Among the Dothraki, the man who does not ride was no man at all, the lowest of the low, without honor or pride. “Let everyone see him as he is.” – Daenerys III AGOT

Dany understands that Dothraki culture strongly associates strength with the ability to ride. So she makes a conscious choice to show all of the khalasar what Viserys really is, showing herself stronger than her brother. And we start to see just how much Viserys ignorance is detrimental to his potential ability to lead the Dothraki:

(…) the Dothraki had laughingly called him Khal Rhae Mhar, the Sorefoot King. Khal Drogo had offered him a place in a cart the next day, and Viserys had accepted. In his stubborn ignorance, he had not even known he was being mocked; the carts were for eunuchs, cripples, women giving birth, the very young and the very old. That won him yet another name: Khal Rhaggat, the Cart King. Her brother had thought it was the khal’s way of apologizing for the wrong Dany had done him. She had begged Ser Jorah not to tell him the truth, lest he be shamed. – Daenerys IV AGOT

Because Viserys refuses to learn and adapt to other cultures, he loses respects, while Dany gains the respect of the Dothraki. She respects their culture and shows her strength by eating the stallion’s horse, riding with them until the end of her pregnancy, and asserting herself.

This new authority that Dany gains also means that Dany sees herself more and more free of her brother’s influence. She gets the chance of getting a new perspective on Westeros through Jorah, without her brother’s biases:

“The common people pray for rain, healthy children, and a summer that never ends,” Ser Jorah told her. “It is no matter to them if the high lords play their game of thrones, so long as they are left in peace.” He gave a shrug. “They never are.”

Dany rode along quietly for a time, working his words like a puzzle box. It went against everything that Viserys had ever told her to think that the people could care so little whether a true king or a usurper reigned over them. Yet the more she thought on Jorah’s words, the more they rang of truth. – Daenerys III AGOT

She talks with Jorah about if it would be possible for the Dothraki to conquer Westeros, trying to gather the information that she’ll need, and even starts believing that someone else could conquer the Seven Kingdoms (herself):

Dany could not pretend to surprise at the disdain in his tone. “What … what if it were not Viserys?” she asked. “If it were someone else who led them? Someone stronger? Could the Dothraki truly conquer the Seven Kingdoms?” - Daenerys IV AGOT

This is also the book in which Dany starts dealing with the many moral dilemmas that she encounters in her story: she wants to conquer the Seven Kingdoms, but once she sees that Drogo attacks the Lhazareen to fund the invasion, she sees the costs of war for the first time, and stands up to Drogo’s men to protect the women from being raped. Later, after Drogo dies, Dany frees her slaves and asks people to follow her, promising to protect them and care for them:

“You will be my khalasar,” she told them. “I see the faces of slaves. I free you. Take off your collars. Go if you wish, no one shall harm you. If you stay, it will be as brothers and sisters, husbands and wives.” The black eyes watched her, wary, expressionless. “I see the children, women, the wrinkled faces of the aged. I was a child yesterday. Today I am a woman. Tomorrow I will be old. To each of you I say, give me your hands and your hearts, and there will always be a place for you.” – Daenerys X AGOT

But it’s important to note that even though Dany has more power than she starts the book with, for most of the book, the power is not truly hers, it comes from Drogo. Before Dany hatches her dragons, she has to use Drogo’s name to make herself be obeyed, and has to resort to things like bed tricks. Even then, she is not always successful. I think it’s very interesting that before Dany truly has her own power, she has to deal with what any woman would have to deal – trying to manipulate her husband to have power and get what she wants. It’s only at the end of the book that Dany steps up as khaleesi in her own right. Initially, Aggo, Jhogo and Rakharo refuse to follow her because she’s a woman, but Dany insists, because she knows that when she steps out of the fire and shows her strength, the khalasar will follow her:

Wordless, the knight fell to his knees. The men of her khas came up behind him. Jhogo was the first to lay his arakh at her feet. “Blood of my blood,” he murmured, pushing his face to the smoking earth. “Blood of my blood,” she heard Aggo echo. “Blood of my blood,” Rakharo shouted.

And after them came her handmaids, and then the others, all the Dothraki, men and women and children, and Dany had only to look at their eyes to know that they were hers now, today and tomorrow and forever, hers as they had never been Drogo’s. – Daenerys X AGOT

A Game of Thrones is an essential part of Dany’s growth as a leader. She learns that to be respected and accepted, she needs to integrate into the community and understand the culture that she is in. She gains a new perspective on Westeros and on war, frees herself from Viserys’ abuse, and builds the necessary strength and confidence to lead her people in the future.

A CLASH OF KINGS

Now, for the first time in her life, Dany has power on her own, and people look up to her for guidance. To survive the Red Waste, Dany leads by showing an example of strength:

They are not strong, she told herself, so I must be their strength. I must show no fear, no weakness, no doubt. However frightened my heart, when they look upon my face they must see only Drogo’s queen. She felt older than her fourteen years. If ever she had truly been a girl, that time was done. – Daenerys I ACOK

She keeps her people together by respecting their culture and traditions:

Three days into the march, the first man died. A toothless oldster with cloudy blue eyes, he fell exhausted from his saddle and could not rise again. An hour later he was done. Blood flies swarmed about his corpse and carried his ill luck to the living. “His time was past,” her handmaid Irri declared. “No man should live longer than his teeth.” The others agreed. Dany bid them kill the weakest of their dying horses, so the dead man might go mounted into the night lands.

Two nights later, it was an infant girl who perished. Her mother’s anguished wailing lasted all day, but there was nothing to be done. The child had been too young to ride, poor thing. Not for her the endless black grasses of the night lands; she must be born again. – Daenerys I ACOK

She also leads them and keeps them together by showing that she cares about them. She doesn’t see herself above her people, and because of this, she starves with them and cares for them:

Dany hungered and thirsted with the rest of them. The milk in her breasts dried up, her nipples cracked and bled, and the flesh fell away from her day by day until she was lean and hard as a stick, yet it was her dragons she feared for. – Daenerys I ACOK

Doreah took a fever and grew worse with every league they crossed. Her lips and hands broke with blood blisters, her hair came out in clumps, and one evenfall she lacked the strength to mount her horse. Jhogo said they must leave her or bind her to her saddle, but Dany remembered a night on the Dothraki sea, when the Lysene girl had taught her secrets so that Drogo might love her more. She gave Doreah water from her own skin, cooled her brow with a damp cloth, and held her hand until she died, shivering. Only then would she permit the khalasar to press on. – Daenerys I ACOK

She keeps them alive by being pragmatic, like when she insists in entering the abandoned city, breaking the taboo of the Dothraki against such places because they need food:

Other searchers returned with tales of other fruit trees, hidden behind closed doors in secret gardens. Aggo showed her a courtyard overgrown with twisting vines and tiny green grapes, and Jhogo discovered a well where the water was pure and cold. Yet they found bones too, the skulls of the unburied dead, bleached and broken. “Ghosts,” Irri muttered. “Terrible ghosts. We must not stay here, Khaleesi, this is their place.”

“I fear no ghosts. Dragons are more powerful than ghosts.” And figs are more important. – Daenerys I ACOK

And she saves her people by making the sensible choice of sending her bloodriders in different directions to find a way out of the desert:

“What shall we seek, Khaleesi?” asked Jhogo.

“Whatever there is,” Dany answered. “Seek for other cities, living and dead. Seek for caravans and people. Seek for rivers and lakes and the great salt sea. Find how far this waste extends before us, and what lies on the other side. When I leave this place, I do not mean to strike out blind again. I will know where I am bound, and how best to get there.” – Daenerys I ACOK

All of these actions enabled her to keep her khalasar together and keep their loyalty. And after many deaths and suffering, they finally get to Qarth.

But when they arrive in Qarth, there are more challenges. Dany thinks that she’ll find something in the city:

The Bleeding Star led me to Qarth for a purpose. Here I will find what I need, if I have the strength to take what is offered, and the wisdom to avoid the traps and snares. If the gods mean for me to conquer, they will provide, they will send me a sign, and if not … if not … – Daenerys II ACOK

And this quote establishes Dany’s arc in this book very well, because this part of her story is a test for her as a leader, and she learns some important lessons.
